reviewText:
Early Access Review

I armed my twin daughters with shotguns, gave them some ammo and armor and sent them out in the wasteland to scavenge while me and the wife stayed in the shelter sleeping and taking showers... When they got back they had killed 9 people, subdued 5 other people and had a full inventory full of materials, food, water, ammo and fuel... Their stress bar didn't move an inch...

10/10 Would fear my own children over an apocalyptic wasteland again.


(UPDATE)

Well jokes aside, i'm really enjoying the game more and more with the updates. I feel that this game will leave its brand in the history of Resource Management games and can become much more...

That being said, i need to point out that the game is far from perfect.

As it stands at the moment there is an issue with the Shelter raid that can completelly destroy what you worked so hard for or leave a bad taste in your mouth...

Example: This actually happened and caused me to close the game and delete my save file, only so i could start fresh. At a point in the game, i get a message that someone was coming for us... Ok, so what do i do? I open the workbench and see what traps i can make... Wait, no, i cant make anything because i have been using the materials to upgrade vital systems so i can support my increasing population... Ok, then i let the raiders come in and my guys can just slap them around since i had 2 firearms, some ammo and allot of melee weapons...

1 guy comes in and starts banging on the door with a pickaxe... a single guy... I thought well this is gonna be easy, i got 3 people with 15+ STR and the aforementioned weapons...

The dude breaks the door, everyone else cowers into a fetal position and start begging for their lives while the dude just waltzes in, heads for the room where my little girls are and kills one of them just like that... then he just leaves and everyone else goes about their business...

This was total BS and left a bad taste in my mouth.

THIS NEEDS TO BE FIXED!!! If we are attacked we need to be able to fend for ourselves with our weapons, not cower in a corner while psycopath just walks in and kills children unchallenged...

FFS, the girl he killed could have easielly rip his face and shoved it up his ♥♥♥ since she had 13 STR.

Don't get me wrong, despite this situation i still love this game and i will still recomend it but beware if you plan to play it before they fix this since it can really ♥♥♥♥ you off.

reviewText:
I have updated this review after I tried the release 1.0 version. My verdict is largely the same.

The game has definitely improved since my impressions from Early Access, and can, if the developers keep improving it here after release 1.0, in time have enough gameplay to make it fun (not quite there yet). At the moment it has some flaws that makes the game unbearable to play for me.


No in-game pause:
One big flaw is the fact that this the inability to pause in-game.

This is a game about survival where you have to manage a lot of things that constantly degrade and break down and the more people you have and the bigger your shelter gets, the more this will require your attention. Sure, it is no problem at the start, but it quickly becomes a problem. Many of the things require attention fast and especially when a lot of things are happening at once does this problem really show itself. Only way to pause is by going to the options menu where you can't see nor interact with anthing. It is unnecessarily stressing and just makes you frustrated in stead of adding anything to the game.

I cannot for the life of me understand why the game doesn't even pause when you are rearranging the furniture in your shelter. Placing an object one pixel left or right can mean the difference between being able to fit one more object beside it. Either pause while I fiddle with this or give me the option to have objects snap to nearly objects. Rearranging your bunker will quickly take 12-in game hours.


Automation:
This brings us to another big flaw in the game: Automation that doesn't really work.

Release version edit: This has not changed enough. Your people still stand around untill something is 60% bad (60% dehydrated / 60% crapping my pants / etc.). One thing that has changed to the better is, that you can now repair items, while they are being used, so when you repair an item has much less impact on the game -- it has essentially been reduced to a breakdown timer you have to rewind.

Yes, you can automate your people, but this is a badly implemented solution since it means full automation or no automation. Your people (when not on automation) will stand still next to a full container of water and die of thirst if you don't select them and click the water. This is mobile game level of gameplay (= bad).

What this means is that you either let your people do whatever they please (not a very good idea) or you spend most of the game clicking on people and then a bed, shower, toilet, food, water, etc. just to keep them alive and happy. Automation also means they will stand around and do nothing at all until things are nearly broken before even considering fixing anything. They will not maintain equipment which can be a bit annoying because you have to manually repair everything if you need things at peak condition. Even when on automation, they will just stand still in a bunker that is running out of air while alarms are blaring and suffocate. Move 5 metres and live? No, I'll just stand here and die, thank you.

A fix to this would be to make automation much more fine-grained. If I, for example, could tell everyone to sleep if they are tired (20%/40% or more) and there is a free bed, then I would not have to keep doing boring things. Make auto-sleep/drink/poop/etc. an upgrade, if you really think micromanaging is a good thing when you start a new game. The release version has the automation fixed for everything at 60%.


Interface:
Last thing that makes me not like playing the game is the interface.

You will most likely play zoomed out since that shows you your entire shelter and let's you see and react to everything, that is going on inside it. Zoomed in (default view mode) is like playing with your face smooshed against the screen. So, it is a good thing that you can zoom out.

Problem is, that if you click the expand button on the selected character, it effectively covers up all of the entrance area of the shelter while zoomed out. The expand button shows their needs, so unless you have every single character on auto (which is a bad idea, as I described above) then you will need this info all the time, Since the game does not let you unselect people, you will have to unexpand the info area, then do whatever you need to do and expand it again after. In a game where time keeps running and you are stressed, this goes from being sligtly inconvenient to rageinducingly annoying.

The inability to unselect also becomes tiring really really fast once two or more characters are stading close to each other. Select is left mouse button, move is also left mouse button. Want to select that character A standing next to character B, who is in the middle of doing something? Oops, selected B. Ok, try again. Oops, just told B to move to where you clicked. Ok, remove that move job from B's job queue. Try again. Oops, once again told B to move.

There is an option to cycle through characters in the bunker with Q and E, but if you have more than the starting 4 it really is a clunky way to do it.

Unless people are outside, where there is danger, you almost never use the move command. It is almost exclusively used to move people inside. And even that is not something you need to do very often since they move inside automatically after completing tasks outside. Unless you moved them outside manually and left them there doing nothing, So why left mouse button is overloaded with the move command is anyone's guess. I would call it bad interface design.


Conclusion:
If none of the above things seem like big problems to you, then I think you might enjoy the game. It's a really good idea made by a team that seems to want to make a good game, which is also why I kickstarted the game way back when. For me the flaws outweight the pleasure of playing the game.


TL;DR:
Game has promise, but unless some serious flaws get fixed/design choices are changed (pause, automation, and interface are at the top of the list), I would not recommend this game. If these things get fixed and the gameplay get's fleshed out a bit I think this could be a good game.

reviewText:
Sheltered is a fairly easy game to play.  If you were looking for a hardcore survival game in which every turn could be your last; you may want to look elsewhere. This is recommended to those who just want to relax and explore the world while crafting interesting special items from schematics that you could possibly find out in the wasteland.

Although this game is easy, you can still find yourself playing and losing all track of time.

Negatives:

There are still a few bugs in the game.  One current game breaking bug in which I show in my video below, my expedition team sprite is in the base but they are actually exploring and now they cannot return at all and I have lost my people.

Once you are in your normal routine this game will become quite mundane quickly.

There's no real need to upgrade everything in the base right away. As long as you have enough people around to fix the durabilities of whatever needs it, you'll be fine.

No real story to go on.  You're just tasked to keep up your shelter all the while managing who comes in and out.

You will find that instead of surviving" that you're just waiting around for the right amount of materials to craft your next item
date:
which for some uncanny reason you won't find for many many days.

Food and water is trivial and many more items seem worthless (like books and records and stuffed bears) after just a couple of weeks game time.

Positives:

This game does a good job keeping you playing as there is a ton of cool stuff to craft.  Although some of them are absolutely unneccessary it does add fun factor to the game.

Your party gain experience in their base stats and will level up enabling them to perform their functions better.  This gives a good incentive to keep people around who are good and will only become more overpowered over time.

https://youtu.be/GpYXrtGW0gM
Overall:

Truthfully there's nothing wrong with this game... it's just painfully easy. The reason why I am not recommending this game is that it's just a "forgettable" game.  This is one of those times in which I wish I could rate this a 5 out of 10."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been following Sheltered since kickstart and while I missed the actual campaign.   I am really glad I decided to pre-purchase the game and support the developers.  While I have only played the game for a little more than hour or so I am impressed with what the developers have done so far.  The game while pretty simple does have many of the game mechanics working.

The game at first might seem a bit confusing.  I did not even bother with the tutorial, someone mentioned on another review that it was lacking anyway, I figured my first game was going to be a disaster so why not have some fun and dive right in.  It did take me about 15 minutes to figure out what the hell was going on and how to start properly manage my family a little better.  The curve seems high at first but is hardly anything to other games I have played in the past.

EDIT
I did noticed a couple size scaling bugs and some mouse issues but those are pretty minor in my own opinion for a pre-release game.  I just reset and have not had the issue again. I found a couple more bugs.  I realized I could not name my children and some of their physical attributes could not be changed.  Nothing game breaking.

My first game I played until I ran out of food.  Granted the first 5 days or so were basically a total waste.  I love the concept of this game.  There is a lot of strategy involved with the decisions you make, which increases the replay factor considerably.  Personally I think what make these types of games so great, the uncertainty of the future.  The game presents quantifiable consequences to almost every decision.  You have one gas mask left.  Your family is down to 4 units of food.  You need a piece of rope to create a trap that will provide food your family needs.  You decide on one last expedition.  You pull out your map.  You choose to go….

EDIT
Well I went south.  Which was not the best decision.  I ended up coming home empty handed to a house full of sick people.  It turns out your generator is connected to your water supply.  I was kind of curious if there was a purpose other than to provide light.  I was able to explore some more and ended up recruiting a couple people with the idea I would keep my family safe on auto pilot while my new minion militia searched for goods, unprotected of course... I will show them to try and unionize... Anyway, they bring back equipment.  I make the shelter better, and then when they die.  I harvest them to eat.  Now I have all the food I could ever dream of having and once I added another water container I was set.  I began sending 4 minions out at a time.  Finished 2 more rooms, upgraded my water, and air to level 2, added some more amenities, but then ran into another issue.  I think I might need to focus a bit more on the leisure items because my family ended up going insane with all the cannibalism i think and the game ended around day 30.  I am raising my initial review to 18 now... for bringing out the hidden Dahmer in me.   Awesome!!!

18/10

reviewText:
First 6 hours, I was just like just wondering how great the game is, at 14 hours I feel disappointed. Was this all there is? The game is too short, too easy and after the beginning there is nothing much actually to do except run around gathering resources to build more unnecessary gadgets. At 200+ days now and I just built 5 plant stations and tore them down right away just to get the achievement. Got my shelter maxed out in space and spend my days painting the walls in different colours.

There are also some balancing problems, I've had my shelter attacked 4 times, twice the attackers backed down before breaching my doors and the two other attacks ended up in the attackers stealing something, I don't know what it was and their attack did not hinder my progression in any way (some items i guess). Same goes for the fights in the wasteland, in 99 out of 100 combats the enemy is dead before they can make their first move.

If you want few hours of fun, wait for 50-75% discount.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Sheltered is so much fun, that I spent way too many hours playing it when I should have been sleeping. Don't be fooled by the simpler design of this game, as it actually adds a lot to its charm. In the beginning you start out confused and lost as you struggle to keep your family alive and well. Every tiny decision you make, even mild, will somehow matter when that one unit of water could have prevented one of your characters from dying.

When you play more, the more you actually learn how you are supposed to do things the right way. Generally I really like the fact that the tutorial is ambiguous, this adds to the fear and confusion of what a real apocalypse would feel like. Intelligent players will enjoy the challenge of figuring things out for themselves, while others may find this annoying.

The pet feature is one of my favorite aspects with the game, as they add a lot of fun, and can prove to be extremely important in the future. I hope to see different pets added in the future, parrots, turtles, rabbits, and even cows could all have their own odd little perks. Skins on certain animals would also be awesome too, having a black cat, or a pug dog could add to the personalization and attachment to the creature.

Cons about this game would mainly lie on the lack of dialogue, and affects of recruiting certain people. Dialogue is often repeated and the same from every character, it would definitely be more interesting to see if what some says depending more on the traits you chose prior. Not to mention the fact that I got bored of the exact same diary entries all the time as they were almost all the same. Adding some diversity would really help enhance this.

-spoiler alert (kind of not really)- Time to address the pink elephant, the cannibal that randomly ends up being completely normal. I'm sure a lot of you have come accross this, you accidentally recruited someone who actually seems super suspicious by saying your family sounds delicious. Well it REALLY is irritating when you find out there is literally no repercussions for this, sure they might eventually leave and mess with something if they start dying from lack of supplies, but so does EVERY other survivor you recruit. Proper repercussions from certain actions would avoid strange conflictions like this. -spoiler end-

I also wish there was another way to defend yourbase other than the reinforcing of the door, or traps. Otherwise they come in and everyone, even courageous people, curl up in a ball and let the intruders take everything, even if said intruders actually is only one person. To be honest there are people who would just get too scared to react, but there are a lot of people who would defend themselves and attack the intruders. Maybe I'm just not doing things right, but it would be nice.

Those are the only things that particularily annoy me, but every game has flaws. The fact that even some people lose sanity over time is interesting, and the amount of details and features put into the game are really just amazing. If you enjoy post apocalyptic games with a wonderful soundtrack, and fun gameplay, then this game is definitely worth the cash.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do I feed my dog or my wife? *whistle* Here boy!
Plot
Sheltered is a game that follows a family that you create, made up of 2 parents, 2 kids and a family pet. Your family is in a fallout bunker hence sheltered and this is where you can start playing. The idea is to survive but how you do that it's up to yourself.

Gameplay
You spend your time in the shelter controlling your family and taking care of their needs, this can also be set to auto pilot. When in your shelter people can approach it asking for refuge or wanting to trade. Then you have the scavenging side of the game, you can send parties of 2 into the wasteland to look for loot. When you do this they leave the shelter area and will radio if there is a problem, if there happens to be a problem in the wasteland (pfft its likely :P) You can take control of the situation which will put you were your scavengers are, these can be from people wanting to kill you, join or trade. With your newly scavenged loot there is a crafting side to the game were you can start decorating your shelter and provide a better life for your family.

Final Conclusion
This game is still in early access, with active devs, they just released an update last week or so with some new items and bug fixes. They have planned on having events when your shelter will be attacked and they were talking about redoing the combat. The game captures the feeling of the apocolypse, referring to the title that happened, she's dead...

Personal Quote
I am your Overseer! Now go clean up my dogs poo and go outside without a gas mask on."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What Can I say about Sheltered?

...

Sheltered is the latest in a long line of survival games that pits you more against the elements and random encounters than zombies and monsters, you start the game by generating your Nuclear family from a list of cookie cutter options that all have strengths and weaknesses, while this would feel limiting in a lot of games it works well in Sheltered and adds emphesis to the role that you have for each character on building new gear, maintaining your dwelling, seaching the wastes for new gear and resources and the interactions you have with others.

Characters gain experience over time and slowly level up there stats the more they are used (this feature still seems to have a few bugs, but hey, it's early access.) which allows you to work more effectively and keep your family alive longer.

you will have opportunities to meet new people, trade with them, recruit them into your shelter, attack them and ultimately when one of your beloved family members bites the big one you can bury them or... *dry heaves a little* Harvest" them to help maintain your rations.

Ways to die in Sheltered are numerous
hoursPlayed: Starved
voteText: Dehydrated
helpfulPercent:
Food Poisioning and Radiation poisoning just to list the ones I have discovered.

so... Is it worth the price of admission?

Pros
-Fun Game play in a randomly generated world.
-Sense of achievement when you unlock the next tier of crafting items
-Ability to eat the corpses of your Kin
-Currently a steady flow of updates (3 content updates in the first week of release)

Cons
-Early Access means bugs and some semi broken features (game on a whole plays fairly smoothly though)
-Some of the UI needs to be improved upon

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I started watching the Kickstarter Campaign a year ago I expected this project to die somewhere in development as most Kickstarter Campaigns go. Passion for the project fades, a tragedy of some kind forces a dev to retire, Internal conflict destroys the startup of the endeavour right from the get-go or the money just gets blown on unnecessary hardware.

Well, and then this happened. This Early Access hit me off-guard like a broadside.

Let me start this on the right note: At the moment you're very much investing in development. The Keymapping is suboptimal and pretty much laid-out for consoles (they even still show the button prompts for XBOX), The playable introduction is threadbare and at the moment there is not really much that you can do. You start with an underground hole with only the barest (and I mean BAREST) essentials and then slowly watch your in-game family die of Radiation poisoning and food spoilage in glorious Pixel-art sprites.

I believe this game will go down the same way as THE MASTERPLAN or Prison Architect went. The first Early Access versions to these to MAGNIFICIENT Indie games with interesting, non-mainstream concepts and well-rounded execution were mere tech demos compared to what Shark Punch and Introversion Software have given us; Complex and detailed simulations with fleshed-out consistent features and LOADS of depth. So, go to the Kickstarter https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/29211325/sheltered/description and look what this game will be, and then decide if you're gonna spend money on ambition.

I did, and I'm hoping you'll do the same.

reviewText:
TL:DR at the end, scored 5 / 10 as of 16th April 2016
Borba likes:Genre - A 2D Indie survival simulation game, with elements of strategy and some RPG mechanics, in which you have to build and maintain your nuclear shelter while keeping your family safe. It provides random elements such as the map, encounters and events, and allows a certain degree of character and shelter customization.

Graphics - Gorgeous retro graphics, characters with interesting and complex animations and a good variety of backgrounds for encounters on the world map are a joy to watch. Even simple details such as the weather effects, graphical changes to the items we upgrade, or being allowed to paint our shelter’s walls add a lot the the game’s mood and post-apocalyptic setting.

Music - From a melancholic, yet soothing melody, to an active bassy combat tune, the game nails it in the music department, as it benefits both the theme and the mood of the game. It doesn’t feel repetitive, despite not having much variety.

Sound - The sound effects, especially ambient ones such as wind and rain, are pleasant and absolutely necessary. Interaction and combat sounds are well designed, although Borba feels that all characters lack some sound effects, in and out of combat, since it breaks the immersion a bit. Some gibberish voices like in The Sims and some “Oof...” and “Argh!” would be a nice addition.

Polish - After several hours of playtime, there was no single crash or major bug, which is a plus. There was a minor bug caused by doing a series of events while in the shelter screen and the time is fast forwarding, resulting in being unable to do anything until escape would be pressed, but that’s a minor issue that may be solved in the future.
Borba dislikes:Replayability - Although the game seems to be thought out for replayability, the lack of story or lore, the shallow interaction with npcs and the repetitive gameplay mechanics botched it for Borba. After getting the first essential upgrades going, survival becomes trivial, since there is little to do other than wait for a specified amount of resources to get the next upgrades, and this can be achieved with little effort simply by doing trades with NPCs. While the map encounters and the shelter attacks could breathe some challenge into the game, they’re just monotonous and far too easy to deal with, and sadly Borba didn’t get any interesting quest or the new “Family Ties” scenario which grants an additional family member and the opportunity to move to a new shelter.

Narrative - The lack of lore or story do this game more harm than good, since there is little motivation to play once a player learns the basics and manages to reach the point in which it’s impossible to lose, which doesn’t take that much time.

Gameplay - The gameplay can be summed up as a point and click time and resource management, with some helpful hotkeys added to the mix. The combat is turn based, while the management phase is real time, allowing players to speed up time at the click of an on-screen button or the press of a key ( shift ). Overall, despite it working well for this type of game, the management becomes far too repetitive and tedious without any real way of automating certain tasks, such as repairing equipment, cleaning the shelter, or eating meat instead of canned goods.

Interface - A simple interface is not always a good interface, but it's still better than an overly complex and cluttered one. Borba did find some issues with its simplicity, though, for example needing to go over each repairable or upgradeable structure again and again as the biggest part of gameplay, instead of being able to automate some of it and / or have a toggleable menu or management screen to allow for interaction with all these structures. It ends up becoming a chore. There is also a nagging ( somewhat personal ) issue with the selected character’s portrait and stats covering the shelter’s entrance.

Design - Borba has two main issues with the game as it is in its post-release state, namely the base management and the lack of depth. The base management quickly becomes a chore, and it is also the biggest part of the game until players are done with building and upgrading, after which all that remains is the click to repair and click to use gameplay. Characters can have an automation feature on for using the structures that provide for their basic needs, but Borba finds that alone to be insufficient, and believes it should’ve been extended to repairs, harvesting, putting out fires and rebuilding ( animal snares ). The game would then almost play by itself, but that would be due to the lack of depth, as there is little motivation to do anything once players are done with the shelter which, depending on luck and effort, could take a couple of hours. Proper world map events other than repetitive generic encounters, or base events other than the black rain, dust storms and raids, that quickly become irrelevant, would go long ways to improve this game’s value. The raid defense merely consists of hiding the characters while hoping a few traps will deal with the attackers, that is, if they can breach the doors, all in all being a dull event that does not make that much sense, since during the game the characters get weapons, kill bears, wolves and cannibals, but cower away if attacked by a single madman, or a couple of them.
Borba feels like he should recommend the game on a discount, due to the 5 out of 5 score, and that he would very much like to see the game updated to address the flaws he pointed out, as it has the potential of being a must have game for anyone who enjoys survival simulators. As it stands now, it’s an average game that is very enjoyable during its first hours, but all the excitement quickly fades as we realize there’s little motivation to keep playing or to replay the game after reaching a sustainable shelter. It’s a flawed game that looks good and has some interesting ideas, just don’t buy it for its potential, as you might get disappointed in the long run.

5 / 10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A fascinating little roguelike with a great retro-Fallout aesthetic. It's tough and tense, especially as water gets low, though not entirely without frustrations, but at the time of writing, it's an Early Access game, and is pleasingly solid and well-put-together for that. It actually reminds me a bit of Gods Will Be Watching, but more intuitive, and I'd say it's already a better game.

On the downside, it could do with a better tutorial, and a bit more variety in the expeditions would be appreciated, along with a way to set automated behaviour (if water is plentiful, why are thirsty inactive characters getting a drink on their own...?) but it's a very solid start, and I've had a lot of fun with it.

reviewText:
Even coming out of early access, Sheltered still feels like a chore to play.  I never have fun playing through it so after about 20 minutes I quit.  It's just a pain in the butt to constantly click on the radio to accept transmissions.  YES, check the stupid building.  You don't need me to tell you to check it because I sent you guys on that particular path to begin with.

Anyway...Sheltered is a family management game set in the post apocalypse future.  For several hours, you will do a few tasks:

1. Send out members to collect resources.
2. Build crap to better facilitate your family.
3. Fix crap constantly breaking.

This is pretty much it for the first 2-3 hours.  Once you get established, raiders will attack your shelter.  I haven't really experience this aspect of the game yet because I get so bored doing the first three activities.  You can also accept quests and trade with other NPC's.  You are really never in any danger of running out of water, it's the food you have to worry about.

I also started with the horse and never got the full use out of it because I could never find enough wood to build a barn in the initial hour of the game.  So the horse starved to death.  Food is VERY scarce early on.  In my humble opinion the two most important buildings to scavenge every 5 days are barn's and homes.  You need that leather, nails and food to progress past the first hour.

In conclusion, avoid unless you absolutely adore sim type games or you liked This War of Mine. I'm hoping the developer adds some quality of life options such as fullscreen windowed mode and the ability to just accept radio transmissions automatically (I'm serious, it gets extremely tedious).

I don't believe I have to do this, but if you're one of those many people who want to argue with  my review despite not having it in your library and never actually played it, your comments will be deleted and communication with you will be blocked.

Early Access
Of course it's early access.  And early access games deserve honest reviews in the state they are in.  This review is for the game it is, not the game it wants to be.  Right now, Mad Games Tycoon, Salt and Dig or Die take up most of my time, all Early Access games which I'd highly recommend.

I want to like it.  I really do.  If you look at my library, I basically play nothing but strategy games.  But at this point, I simply can't recommend it.  Perhaps when things get ironed out.  But it's pretty raw and boring at this point.

Time in game
I've played the game for about four hours.  A couple of people have said that four hours isn't long enough to give an accurate review which I find to be a non-sensical comment.  You either like the game and give it a fair shot or dont.  Four hours is plenty of time to get used to the UI (which is very clunky and non-intuitive in this game), get an idea of the realism" the game intends to portray and have an idea whether the game is well put together.

Positive Points. Developer
The developer is quick to respond to criticism and throw out ideas

The game certainly has the potential to be an addicting game.

I've noticed very few bugs in the game.  The bugs I can recall have either been fixed or only happened on one occasion.

reviewText:
Similar to some other commends, while this game could possibly be enjoyable if you like tedious, repetitive gameplay, the game has too much emphasis on the basics of building things to make sure your family doesn't die, and fixing stuff that breaks constantly. While raiders start attacking your base after you have built the skeleton of your base, the dull and almost annoying tasks of having to manage your base overwhelm any desire to keep playing to this stage.

I think in theory if the game's UI and management system made simple tasks a lot more streamlined (responding to distress signals, anyone?) the game would suddenly become a lot more enjoyable. However, considering this feedback was given during Early Access and little to no work has been done on this now that it has released, I have doubts that the developers are planning on implementing anything like this in the future.

My opinion is to wait for an exceptionally good Steam Sale.

TL:DR This game is fun, enjoyable, challenging, and replayable. Since it's a pre-alpha thing, I hope they add some more features to he game and to improve the tutorial.
.
.
When I first started the tutorial, it was helpful, but then after a couple steps you play the real game without any more help. I didn't like that at first, but I learned a lot by myself. What I like a lot abou this game is that there's a lot of things to learn and places to explore on your own and you need to prepare for it.Strategize!  At first glance, I found myself juggling between the 4 family members on who needs water, who's sleep deprived, who needs anti-ratiation medicine, is the dog bowl filled, both kids are starving...all of this hits you at the beginning of your first week of survival and it's really hard to catch up at times, but once you pick yourelf back up, it leads to a lot of productivity to expand your shelter.
.
To add to this game, I would say an Easy/Normal/Hard game mode would be better since the timing of the gameplay actions feel very rushed. The timing of everything is a bit overwhelming at first but you get used to it.

There's a lot about this game that I like, such as the artwork, exploration, underground expansions, and even recuiting more people to your cause. It's definately a game worth to try out.

reviewText:
Sheltered is a 2D post-apocalyptic survival game in which your objective is to survive for as long as possible. Manage your own shelter and family as they face resource scarcity, diseases, moral dilemmas, stress and trauma. Your family has established themselves in an old bunker and it’s here where you’ll spend your last days on Earth.

Gameplay overview:
Before going into the game, you get a chance to give your own personal touch to your family, which is constituted by 4 members, 2 adults and 2 children. You can customize their appearance, as well as choose a different trait and set of stats for each. You can also choose to have a pet such as, a snake, a cat or a dog, each one having their own pros and cons. Despite initially choosing a set of stats for your family members, these can be improved by fighting or talking your way out with strangers. You’re also able to recruit more people to your shelter but these will start out by acting automatically in your shelter, you’ll only be able to order them around and send them on expeditions when their loyalty is high enough.

Your initial shelter is pretty basic and lacks most essentials so you’ll need to get your hands to work from the get go. It is vital that you keep an eye on your shelter systems conditions and repair them so that they don’t go bad. Things like the water filter and air filter should always be in good shape in order to prevent disasters. The water filter is particularly important because it allows you to gather water when it rains. However, if it starts raining “black rain”, you have to watch out because your water will get poisoned. There are also other events that might take place on your base, such as dust storms, raids or being approached by traders and people who’re looking for a roof above their heads.

That said, there are other ways for you to gather water and resources necessary to crafting, upgrading and expanding your shelter. You can send a maximum of 2 of your people away on expeditions by using a radio. There is however two things you must, or should, have when preparing these, enough water to endure the trip (otherwise the game won’t let you) and gas maks to protect yourself from radiation poisoning. On the world map, you’ll be able to set a series of waypoints for your party to go through and you’ll also be able to see various different buildings that you can search, each with certain types of items and resources. Still, you can’t just hoard everything you find because your characters have an inventory limit (as does your shelter), so you should know what you’re looking for and craft bags in order to carry more items.

The game is divided into two different styles of play. Combat is turn-based and the management part is in real-time, with the option to speed up time. Combat is pretty simple and it plays like most turn-based RPGs out there, attack, defend or try some other special move on the enemy, rinse and repeat. As for the management side, it plays pretty much like a point and click game, select a character and click what you want to interact with. You’ll need to be able to keep up with your shelter needs early on, which include, cleaning, repairing, fueling the generator, and keep your family needs satisfied. This involves a great deal of micromanagement, so depending on your tastes, you’re either going to find it really addictive or really repetitive.

Pros:Gorgeous pixel art style
Great atmosphere
Highly replayable
Great mix of RPG and management elements
Cons:Journal entries and conversations can get repetitive
No storyline
Overall Sheltered has been a rather amusing and fun experience. From dealing with people trying to force their way into my shelter, to bullying grown ups with my kids, the game has it all. You can even eat your dead family members! Still, I feel like the game could’ve been much more if it focused just a little on story or character interactions. Your family members feel like they’re just part of a big machine and it seems they share no love between them.

It is the different take on a post-apocalyptic scenario by mixing RPG and real-time management elements that make this game worth checking out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR: I can see loads of potential in this game. If they will add features to the combat system and include factions or organized gangs, this would be close to 10/10 in my books.

Review:

The premise is a post-apocalyptic world where resources are scarce and the surface is more or less hostile to human life. The art style is pixelated which I personally quite like.

You start by creating a family of four persons: two parents and two kids. You stumble across a shelter that has some basic equipment in it like a radio, crafting table and a life support system (water and oxygen filter). You can occasionally send an expedition team of max. two persons at a time to explore the surroundings for resources like food, water, crafting materials, weapons etc. You will also need to keep the place clean, because rats will start to appear and they will eat your food. Medicating your survivors in case of radiation poisoning or infection is also vital.

You can upgrade your shelter with the crafting table and even upgrade the crafting table itself to allow yourself to manufacture more advanced items.

Resource management is important, since your survivors need to eat, drink, sleep, shower and go to the toilet every once in a while. Showering and going to the toilet consumes water so the game requires you to plan carefully. Expeditions also require water, the further you want to explore, the more water you will need. You can upgrade the maximum capacity of your water storage by building more reserves. You will also need a pantry to store all the food, the bigger the better.

You will meet other people in the wasteland. Some will knock on the shelter door, looking to either trade or join your shelter, and some will appear when you are out on an expedition. Recruiting other people can be useful but I wouldn't recommend getting additional people if the shelter supplies are running low. Trading systems doesn't use any kind of currency (like bottlecaps) which is ok for me. Instead items have a certain value (Nail=1, Sand=2, Shotgun=200) and you can trade something in equal of value.

The combat system is pretty basic, but I wasn't bothered by it too much. My only wish is that the developers would implement some kind of percentage system in the combat. In many situations I wasn't sure if I should stay and fight or just flee. It would be nice to get some odds on my chance to hit or counter an attack. You can improve your character's combat stats (Agility and Strenght) by making a punching bag.

Also it would be pretty awesome (in my opinion) if the game had gangs or other factions or if you could form a faction of your own.

I'm looking forward to the final version!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Imagine taking the majestically jolly Rimworld, taking out the vast majority of the fun, adding a slice of Oregon Trail, and then bolting a big dose of Sims sans DLC on top. You end up with what should be a post-apocalyptic party survival sim, but instead it becomes a time management game about doing your chores (repairing a number of permanently damaged machines that break down every single day of your life) while trying not to commit a whole bunch of poorly communicated mistakes the game wants you to do. And no content, because Sims games without DLC don't have any.


Like Terraria, Sheltered is a game that very much wants you to rely on out of game information to grasp the basic gameplay systems (like the completely unexplained character traits and the very counter-intuitive role that character stats play). In a system of Intelligence-Charisma-Perception-Dexterity-Strength in the context of a post-apocalyptic handyman simulator, you'd expect intelligence and perception plus maybe dexterity to play roles in how well and how swiftly your craftsman repairs the power generator, while charisma might be relevant to keep your survivors surviving sanely as a group (seeing how there's also an Optimism trait). However,

Intelligence = Used in recruitment" attempts. The higher the number the better the chance you have of recruiting them.
Charisma = Used in "trade" attempts. The higher the number the better the chance of getting "good" trades with NPCs.

Just why. Why.
(Because Sheltered has the design complexity of a phone game and we can't have multiple stats interact with each other
date: nor can we have stats actually do anything meaningful beyond a die roll

reviewText:
Early Access Review

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UdAAS3Z2mhs

My wife is named Jason... Funny? Definitely! This is just one of many of the small bugs in Sheltered in it's initial release state at the time of this review. This fun and challenging survival game is very playable in it's current state. The price is well worth the investment and the developer seems serious about continuing to build a great game and a great reputation.

While I have just scratched the surface...quite literally. I have found this to be a great combination of 60 Seconds, This Life of Mine and Fallout Shelter. This is the type of game where you will find yourself away from the PC, contemplating new approaches and tactics.

The serious tone of the environment makes you realize that small mistakes quickly and almost always lead to big problems. Some balancing and tweaking is undoubtedly on the horizon, but it's just polish on an already gem of a dusty bleak survival game that truly stands out among the over-saturated genre.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First version of the review in August 2015:
Summary: It's the most anticipated game by me in 2015, but I can't recommend it in its current state.

Now it's end of February 2016 (~6 months later).

I still cannot recommend it.
Yeah I tried to play it, it has given me some fun, but still a looooooong way to go.
Yeah the developers are working on it, fixing stuff, adding new content.

But it's just the feeling that it's not good enough.

Some thoughts below.

Character attributes:
It's so dumb. Strength - attack in combat. Dex - chance to escape. Int - recruitment success (?). Boring and not very meaningful.

Shelter:
Crafting and managing your shelter is ok, but lacks polish. You build a lot of water tanks and you can forget about improving toilets or showers. There is no need to upgrade your systems other than workbench.

Shelter Events:
Guy that comes to the shelter for food and breaks the filters is simply annoying. Let me kill him.
Raids are poorly implemented.
Guys coming to join you - just annoying.
Traders - OP. (You can broadcast signal for traders to come to your shelter) - Honestly I could just make water and trade it, not balanced. Trading UI annoying.

Fights / Encounters:
You pick two characters with Strength ~9-10 and a Dog companion (super OP) and rule the wastelands with pipes.
Encounters are mostly dumb. Recruitment does not make sense. Trading is weird. Stat progress is strange.

User Interface:
Pain.

I will update this review in another 6 months, but...Meh.. I really wanted this game to be good...

voteText: 17 of 26 people (65%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Sheltered is a survival game, focused on protecting your family of four - two adults and two children.  Almost all of the interactions happen in your shelter, but you have to send out family members on expeditions to search for useful items.  All family members have various status bars, for hunger, thirst, sleepiness, needing to use the bathroom, and hygiene. They also have status bars for stress and one for trauma.  It's important to balance the needs of the family with the risk of going out and gathering supplies.

The only time you actually see anything outside your shelter walls is when an expedition encounters any other people while out and about.  Those encounters can result in trading, recruiting new people to your base, or fights.  Fighting is very simplistic - not a lot of nuance, it's mostly choosing to hit the enemy and hopefully kill them before they kill you.

Sheltered is an enjoyable addition to the survival game genre, though a little steep in price for the content.

Since I've seen a lot of reviewers do personal scales, and it's helped me a lot to decide what to buy, I put my own here.  I give Sheltered a 3.  Additionally, I usually only give a thumbs up if I got at least two hours of enjoyment out of it for every dollar I spent, and this game did that.  (It wouldn't have if I hadn't bought it on discount, however.)

5: Amazing game, easily worth the full price.
4: Good game, solid addition to the genre, might want to wait for a discount.
3: Pretty entertaining game, but some issues.  Buy at a discount unless you love the genre.
2: More cons than pros, a lot of issues.  Only buy with a strong discount, and only if the game truly sounds like something you'd enjoy.
1: Don't get this game unless it's free.  Even then, consider spending your time playing something decent.

For more specific pros and cons, read on.

Pros:
Ability to customize your family is great, especially being able to have same-gender parents, and there are a wide range of skin colors.  It's still rare enough to encounter that in games that I was pleasantly surprised.
Getting to choose a specific pet with its own unique benefits was also great.
The game starts off with the right blend of desperate food/water/fuel searching and trying to find items to upgrade.
Crafting was well-done - slowly getting the supplies to replace crappy versions of items with better ones.
Though there are a lot of stock phrases, I like that there are different types of people you run in to/that come visit you.
I really enjoyed that the kids aren't any worse at doing tasks than the adults.  That made them useful members of the shelter instead of a drain on food.
I know some people will dislike it, but I enjoyed hunting down the blueprints for the best crafted items.
The ability to change the random weakness into a positive (and have the positive change in to a negative if enough bad things happen) was really awesome - I enjoyed the puzzle of figuring out how to change them.  (Never figured it out for my pessimist, though.)
Cons:
The graphics.  They'll be a turn-off for a number of people.  Some things are fine - the backgrounds are great, for instance.  But the people and some of the items are so incredibly hard to look at and figure out what they are.  My cat is an orange blob, for instance.  I've played a lot of pixel art games, and this is pretty bad.
The difficulty curve starts off great - tough on your first playthrough/your first few days, then gets a bit easier as you get more supplies.  The problem, however, is once you get your base set up and you have a ton of supplies, food, fuel, water.  Almost all survival games have a point where survival itself becomes trivial.  The good ones have something new at that point, someplace new to explore, new fights (or bosses) to take on, new quests.  Sheltered doesn't, really.  You can move on with your family and join a distant relation in a new area, but that doesn't add much.  You start off with tons of supplies you bring with you, and at that point, surviving with 5 people isn't that much worse than surviving with 4, and as far as I could tell, there was no actual difference in the new region versus the old one.
The only puzzle in the game with some unique loot is hidden behind a locked door that you can only open if you happened to choose the right pet at the start of the game.  There's no way to change your pet - your only option is to start your game over.  This was incredibly annoying and disappointing - I hate it when game things are locked behind early game choices, especially when there's absolutely no indication this will happen.
One of the fighting options, subduing your enemy, is either bugged or just ridiculously difficult to pull off.  There's an achievement for it, so I spent literal hours trying to do it.  Nothing.  This means your only real choice is to kill them or run away.
I disliked the fact that your family could keep on working even with their sleep bar filled up to the max.  It made the game too easy once I discovered this - aside from a couple of very minor things (training to raise stats), sleepiness affected nothing, unless at least one other bar was also near the max.  (This increases stress, which was negligible with the pet cat.)  I really wish there had been some penalty here - I had one person stay up for 20 days straight.  Additionally, I think being able to send people out on expeditions when they have any bars near max is a bad idea - if it was changed, it would encourage people to switch out teams and make sure they take care of their family.  (Though it'd have to be balanced with people starving and needing to forage for supplies, I suppose.)
I did enjoy the game.  It was definitely entertaining, especially at the beginning.  I hope they continue to update it and I can come back in a year and be amazed at all the positive changes.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a game about family and its survival, rather than the usual cliché of killing monsters in a post-apocalyptic world. From the point at which you create your cast, assigning them names and traits, to when they pass away and you have to make the difficult decision of whether to harvest their body just to keep your other members alive… you’ll feel the emotion of the household, and guilt at knowing you perhaps could have done better by them.

Sheltered’s downside is that it becomes a little repetitive after a few hours. It’s possible to have your expedition party automatically take care of any encounters out in the wilderness and to semi-automate some actions back in the bunker; but reducing your level of control in this way could result in some unwanted outcomes. I also like to have an end objective and it wasn’t entirely clear whether there was something I should be working towards, or if it was just a case of surviving as long as I possibly could.

Saying that however, this is an addictive title despite still being in early access. I ended up playing for three hours after planning to only spend an hour with Sheltered on my first go, and managed to survive for a total of twenty-four days before I called it quits for the evening. It's just a shame we had to eat the cat.

Full details can be found here:
http://1001up.com/2015/10/16/preview-sheltered/

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI love this game! Although the user interface is a little difficult to learn at first, I have to say that I'm rather impressed with it so far. I like that there is plenty to do and that it still captures the essence of survival and the benefit of trading/cooperating with others in hardship. It's a lot more basic than This War Of Mine, but in some ways I see it as a benefit because the strategy for survival wasn't as difficult in this game. In my opinion, the price is a bit steep for something still in early access, but I honestly don't regret buying it at all. I look forward to seeing more developments, and I anticipate spending a lot of my time playing this little gem.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe game is very addicting and getting started can be difficult because the events of the game appear to range from completely random tries to kill you as soon as possible or guides you to end-game easily and everything in between.  The biggest problem I have with this game is once you get the recycling station in tier 4, the game loses all semblance of challenge and you basically are left exploring the game for..... Yeah I don't know why you would continue at that point.  There's nothing to work toward, nothing to do (other than micromanage people's poop, shower, and maintennance schedules and send a patrol/scout party out to interact with people - but once you have your base set up with the shotguns pointing at the entrance and the recycling station, the game is cake and loses its purpose.  I'd like to see more end-game survival content other than a hey you made it now just do whatevers kind of end-game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is my first review on Steam. I feel obliged to write one because this really is a great game that deserves support from the community.

If you're like me, then this is the game you've been waiting for. It's a family-sized vault survival game, similar to FTL in micromanagement and Fallout Shelter iOS app in gameplay. You go out and search for supplies, encountering friendly and dangerous NPCs along the way, all to scavenge stuff to help your family back at the fallout shelter survive. when you have encounters outside the vault, the setting changes to that encounter, which may result in combat, or not, depending on you. I think this is really cool.

You expand the shelter as you go, building and upgrading new useful things, whilst mainly worrying about food and water. Expansion of the shelter is one of the coolest features, as you get to decide in what order your family's survival priorites are.

This game is not for babyshit survivalists. This will adequately simulate the hopelessness, desperation, and satisfaction of fallout shelter life. You will get radiation poisoning. You will get food poisoning. You will experience dehydration, starvation, desperation, and elation as you find that little bit of food or water or whatever that will keep your family going for a few more days.

A few features of the game do need a little tweaking at the moment, but that's fine because THE DEVS ARE LISTENING! I know this for a fact because I've personally seen it. The alpha has been released for the best possible reason - to improve an already great game.

Overall, for 15 bucks, this is a great buy. Even in early access, the game is very playable, with no gamebreaking bugs of any kind that I've found. If you enjoy basically anything post-apocalyptic, the novel The Road, or, specifically, the Fallout Shelter iOS app, this game is for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The stories in this game are great. here's my first experience with the game.

Day 1: The family find a disused shelter, they move in

Day 2: Our first expedition! My son and I go out looking for something... anything
My son is attacked by a bandit, and requires medical attention. I kill the bandit.

Day 4: My son dies from Radiation Poisoning, apparently it wasn't a good idea to send him up to fix the Air Filter after all

Day 5: Soon realise his corpse is going nowhere... it stinks in here, the wife is going crazy - my daughter is using up the last of the water in the damn shower. Things are getting a bit crazy.

Day 6: Food is all gone... I wonder what human flesh tastes like...

Day 8: RAIN! We have rain.

Day 10: My wife and daughter are off in search of supplies. Someone is at the bunker door, Lisa is her name. She's joining us... despite the fact we have no food and very little water - even Jasper the cat is about dead.

Day 12: Everyone died.

I don't actually know what happened, I was skipping through time in fast mode and then it said something along the lines of Everyone's dead
date: time survived: 12 days". I think this is a bug
recommended: as we were mostly still alive.\n\nThis game has promise
hoursPlayed: I look forward to see it progress in development!\n"

reviewText:
Stating out with little knowledge of the game, and its mechanics was a lot of fun.
Having sold most meds early on for other goods...the wife of the family died from radiation poisoning.  The father of the family died in the shower soon after that.
I failed to notice he was bleeding, and I didn't have the resources to bury either the father or the mother.

Tsunami trauma level for the two remaining kids.

Now the father had brought back a teddy, but seeing I had not built a toy-box, and the kids apparently can't fetch the fluffy out of the bottomless box of wonders, things went even more downhill.

There are plenty of quirks, and the game can get really repetitive and dull.

However, It's not a bad game, and I recommend it as it's not expensive for the hours of fun it can provide.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I kinda bought this expecting a short quick time waster
Boy Was I Surprised !!!
You see this is a game thats bathed in hidden things that are bound to keep you trucking on through the apocolypse.
The first thing you'll notice about this game is that it barely holds your hand, no mommy's love for you, certainly not. instead you and your wife and your 2 kids are thrust into a semi operational bunker with basic survival implaments and an urge to not be dead, its kinda like being your own overseerer and makes me feel like getting my jollys back from fallout 3 and new vegas.
speaking of fallout it shares quailitys with bethesdas fallout shellter but takes its props from sims. This leads to intrestiting gameplay more centered on staying alive than building a thriving community.
Its ofcourse not without its flaws but manages to still keep me intrested through the select use of intresting loot mechanics and the best godamn part about this game which so far no other game of this type has mastered.
The mechanic i am ofcourse talking about is the fact that diffrent stations such as your genny and your water filter actually change apparence based on upgrades.....holy ♥♥♥♥ !!
If i had to be honest im still playing this and im still enjoying it mostly because the devs patch game breaking bugs and continue to pump out respectable content wanted by the community.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR at the bottom *and Why I voted no for this game*

Man o' Man have I been waiting to right something about this game! For the past year or so (Been a while) I've been waiting for the release of this game since it was announced on kickstarter. This was the first game I ever donated to as far as crowd funding goes and to be quite honest I didn't expect this game to get made. It took a very very long time for this game to reach its goals and I even became afraid it wouldn't. Luckily it surpassed the goal slightly. Now for a game with a budget of $30,000 it turned out quite well. Now was it worth the wait? Sadly I don't think so. Is it an amazing game? Yes, yes it is. Quite honestly I had even forgot I have contributed to the kickstarter untill I heard the announcment of this game (Oh and when it was on greenlight, Which was also my first time using steam greenlight). But Im glad I contributed to this game. I love its simplicity, and its complexity. Its not some easy game that you can pick up and go. In fact its quite dificult, and I like that. Now its time for the moment of truth...

Summary:
Is this game worth Getting at its current $15 Price point? No
Sadly as Much as I enjoy this game, its just not enough for me to tell people to put this kind of money on it. Now yes it is an early access game but wait till its finished. However, There hasn't been any bugs besides 1 or 2 interface issues from what I have seen
Who is this game for? This game is for people who have time to sit down for hours and play, and who also enjoy post apoctalyptic survival games.
Why no? Because this game is lacking many features that were promised back in June of Last year, Such as Intro story, More in depth character interactions, and even more essential RPG elements. For more info as what I am reffering to just look at the Kickstarter: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/29211325/sheltered/description
My Rating (1 - 10):
If my cat doesn't stop ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in my shelter im going to eat it....
Thats my rating, take it as you wish.

reviewText: I'd absolutely recommend this game. It feels similar to a cross between NEO Scavenger and Fallout Shelter, but ultimately deeper, a bunker simulator set in the post-apocalypse that always has you thinking carefully about your next move. You'll worry about your survivors as they scavenge in the wasteland, and you'll pray for rain to come just so you'll have water to drink. Sickness and hunger are always a concern. There are many very realistic aspects that pull this game together and make it a unique experience all its own, and anyone into survival games should have a blast with it.

reviewText:
It was fun for a bit, but it is still full of bugs.

Base raid had invisible enemy. Worked out fine since combat is turn based, but was confusing.

Individuals seem to randomly die while exploring. Very little explanation as to what you can do to avoid this. Spent many days training dexterity and strength, explore far distances regularly and take zero damage, until suddenly full damage and death.

UI is severely lacking. Stat system is incredibly basic.

Even Fallout Shelter had more depth than this game, and they are essentially the same thing.

Still not sure if it is early access or not. Would probably be okay with my purchase if it was a couple bucks, but $15? Total waste. Very surprised that this is rated 'Very Positive.'

reviewText:
Early Access Review

More like if Another World + Fallout Shelter + Sims + Old School JRPG had a baby.
This game literally just came out and is a lot more playable than many other Early Access games. I attribute Sheltered's Early Access performance to its simplistic design but complex mechanics. It has a very indie feel which I dig. There is a LOT of potential that I am looking forward to as the game continues its development.

The Good
The game is a lot of fun. This survival shelter genre will probably be the new hot thing that a lot of devs are going to start to copy. Lets just hope that Sheltered remains top-notch. I really like the pixelized art, the gameplay is suprisingly complex and varied, and there are some tense and hilarious moments throughout the game. I recommend Youtubing the gameplay to see if you like it because a reading a review doesn't do games any justice.

The Bad
As of right now the game is a bit too difficult. The needs" meter go up too fast and the rate of finding the items you need for your family is too low. I found a few bugs but nothing that couldn't be fixed. The controls can't be changed as of yet so it can be a bit awkward and difficult to micro your units. It was kinda fun figuring out how to do stuff because the tutorial was very lacking. Many people died during my exploration of trying to figure out what I could do and what I couldn't. Don't worry
date: they were harvested for later.\n\nYour doing great Unicube! One of the VERY FEW Early Access Games that I've enjoyed and felt like I am going to get my moneys worth and more. Keep it up!"

reviewText:
Alright, ill give my few cents for a review of the game, as a whole, after about 46 hours of playing...
I'll start off by admitting that i restarted the game a few times, to get things right. First game i got raided pretty early so i thought i would be prepared for that in the next game, altho that happened very late. So i'm guessing those encounters are random from game to game, as to when and how often they happen. And i've only been raided twice, first round they didn't enter, just bashed a bit on the door then left. 2nd time they broke down the doors but got killed by traps and my survivors that was armed.

I've pretty much upgraded everything, might need a single upgrade which i need switches for (hint: if you find switches, SAVE them ;-) That includes finding a lot of blueprints that makes things easier, propably not all the blueprints, but things like the auto pantry that creates food automaticly (1 per 24 hours, per station).

At this point (170 days survived), i got nothing to achive but find a way to get into the mysterious hatch, which theres a code for, which i can't get as i have a pet cat, and not a goldfish (search this for info, if u wish to unlock the mysterious hatch). My survivors take care of them selfs, i repair, fill up the generator and make feed the cat and clean up once in a while... That's it.

The difficulty currently, is too easy, i feel like i need a challenge at this point. To start with, i had problems with water, rations and so on, now... not so much...
For instance more frequent attacks and perhaps them being better armed could be something that should be implemented.
Also the factions i've come across should be harder and hostile, one of them wanted to trade, without me being able to attack or eliminate them, and the area of which they appear in, doesn't change or grow (from my experience).

It's small things you notice that makes the difference, altho the above mentioned things aren't exactly positive feedback, i still have invested 46 hours into the game at this point, and will invest more. It's not a bad game, it just needs some tweaks here and there :)

So ofcourse i'll recommend it, but would also hope, that future updates bring more challenge to the game.

It's fun.

Get it.

reviewText:
A slower-paced crafting survival thriller game in general.

Pros:
- Dark, gritty and detailed pixellated graphics (I personally love pixel graphics)
- Crafting (the meat of the game)
- Thrilling survival management (very similar to Sims - cleanliness, hunger, thirst, stress, trauma, etc.)
- atmospheric sounds and music

Cons: (what I feel may damage gameplay for some gamers)
- slow paced gameplay. If you don't like waiting, this game may not be for you.
- Can get repetitive (mainly point and click interface)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've not played particularly much of this game, however I can safely say that I'm glad I backed the Kickstarter. Even for an early access game, it runs and plays incredibly well, and only suffers from minor issues when it comes to selecting stacked objects/characters, which I'm sure will be improved soon.

Sheltered is a 2D post-nuclear war survival game, where you have to protect a family of 4 (And a cat/dog) in their underground shelter, which starts as poorly prepared and lacking of basic necessities such as, you know, a toilet (I learnt that the hard way). You can send out up to 2 of your family members on an expedition where they scavenge, scout, and interact with survivors.

It should be noted that some of the images shown on the store page are outdated, as I haven't seen some of the UI's in my short time playing.

In the future, I can see Sheltered becoming an incredibly enjoyable, deep, and at times funny game that I'll inevitably lose many hours to.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a good game that needs a LOT of work. Come back to it later and it'll be great!

-Combat is f'd up. (world's most one-sided fist fights mainly)
-Negative status don't do much of anything (especially trauma - you can send your kids to die and eat em with no consequences)
-Highly annoying motor-like sound when you press on fast-forward time, to the point where you just mute all sounds
-Needs bigger map
-Camper is useless- by the time you have it completed you don't need it anymore
-No ending/goal
-No option to play 2 adults only
-Cannot play without scavenging, aka traders that come in your shelter rarely have fuels so you'll run out of fuels and die after 100 days if you try it. (I've tried it)
-REALLY needs vsync

Other than that it's great.
Just come back in a few months.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nVery monotonous.  And seriously - you've got a survivor who can fix generators and upgrade water filtration systems, but they poop on the floor because you didn't tell them to use the toilet in time?  I don't like the way you can only have, for example, one sleeping bag in an entire room in the shelter.  Did we forget there's a depth dimension?  You get radiation poisoning if you go work topside without a radiation suit, but it doesn't _let_ you wear a suit on scavenging trips and you're fine??  Weird control scheme, moronic people, tedious.  It's like my job except I don't get paid for it.  Really interesting concept, but poor execution.  Most people play games to _escape_ from having to do things like clean the toilet, mop the floor, bury the dead, and so on.  Refund requested.

reviewText:
Simple and addictive, but also repetive if you play it 12 hours straight.

You play as a leader of a family of four and you control each member to scavenge, fight, or manage around you base. You can expand your community by recruiting new members and build a bigger shelter. You weapons will also advance from sticks and pipes, to crowbars and knives, and eventually gun. At some point your characters may die, and it may create emotional impact on you, but there is no time to mourn but harvest the body and put the meat in the fridge.

Also, enemies can raid your base, and this is the part where I really dislike the game. You can't arm your members with weapons when you get raided so the fights are quite one sided. You can arm traps that are built inside your base, but you can only start arming when the raid started. Aside from that, the shelter is already cramped with all the other items so traps are just gonna make the shelter even more disorangized. Also, there was no instructions on how to arm traps and I spent 10 mins watching my shelter get rekt wondering when I can't arm a shotgun trap when I have ammo (Turns out I need to craft a trip wire too in order to arm the trap).

It is still a good game though, ate 15 hours straight from me and I am likely to replay it again. This time rushing for police stations and getting all the guns so I can start murdering survivors.

Pros:
-Simple gameplay, low complexity but high depth.
-Customized characters that you grow attach to.
-Crafting, with a large amount of items and materials to fiddle with
-Low graphic entry.
-Base building.

Cons:
-Half-♥♥♥♥♥ tutorial, quite misleading at late game.

Overall:
A total recommend from me. Though I do find it dull when you start rushing the speed up button to get your survivors finish scavenging, it does get fun when you add some narrative in there by doing some role playing.

reviewText:
Having only merely scratched the surface of this game in my 10+ hours of gameplay, I can safely say I'm liking what I've played so far, with still so much more to explore.

This isn't a game that hands you all you need on a silver platter right out the gates.  You're going to have to really scavenge and prioritize and use time management properly.  You start out with a tiny shelter with limited supplies, and it becomes apparent very quickly that you're going to need to remedy your water and food issue rather fast, and fuel as well, because if your generator goes down, everything living in your shelter soon will as well.

The game offers a basic tutorial at the start which is enough to familiarize yourself with the game and controls, after that, it's all up to you.  You can allow new recruits to join, some will become loyal, others will take off and may sabotage your air or water filtration system (bad personal experience in-game lol).  I always enjoy a well-made survival game, and this one is really up there for me for really offering what I need in a survival game, and that's an actual challenge with longevity.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After just a short amount of time playing this, I have to say I'm quite impressed. I had found this game a long time ago on Kickstarter and I've been following it ever since, hoping for the day that it'd come out. As of now, I can say I'm glad I was hoping for this.

The game itself is just what they've been promising a roguelike base and resource manager with the human element and crafting. Being in EA, there's bits and pieces that aren't around, obviously, but currently there's the framework, and it's a pretty good one at that.

That said, I do currently have some problems with it. The main two that annoy me the most are these. 1, people are doggedly persistant in doing the -first- thing you tell them to, and nothing else. So if you accidently click on the surface, well guess what, the darling idiot you told to do that won't stop for anything (even putting on a radiation suit) until you open the doors and let them up there, and get horribly poisoned in the process. 2, they just don't have any minds to their own, you have to literally control every aspect of what they do. I'd kinda wish they were smart enough to eat or drink when you have the stuff available, instead of standing there and whining.

This all said, however, the developers seem like good people who listen and take in feedback, and this game literally came out on Steam like a day ago as of writing this. I'm going to give this a good review, because it's good right now, and can only really get better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Be me, a father of a young boy and younger girl, whose stuck in an underground shelter  fighting for survival in a post-apocalyptic world.

Day 1: Send my wife and son out on an expedition for supplies while my daughter and I fix the water filter and setup a bucket as a makeshift toilet.  After a few hours my wife and son come back with a friend, Diane. Diane says she will die without a shower. Diane builds a shower and proceeds to empty our water tank showering. I resist the urge to strangle Diane.

Day 2: We pray for rain, but the powers that be mock us for Diane's folley. We dig two new rooms for our shelter so we can setup some beds and a second water butt. With no water, we're all filthy... except Diane.

Day 3:  Still no rain. We shoot death glares at Diane as our dog dies from lack of water.  By the end of the day, Diane goes catatonic and begins rocking in a ball on the floor. We've all got to poop, but the toilet bucket is full and no one dares go near it without water to clean it up.

Day 4: Diane dies of dehydration. It's bitter-sweet.  My son and daughter are both puking all over the floors. My wife makes a mop and tries to clean up after them, but she's gone delirious since Diane died.

Day 5: Satisfied with Diane's death, the powers that be open the heavens and give rain water to my dying family. Unfortunately we all die of constipation before we're able to put the water to use.

10/10 would die again.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I recommend this game for the fact that it has alot of aspects that other games do not, such as being able to have a pet at the start and having to take care of it while managing resources.

The game itself needs to become harder becuase right now it is too simple to get everything you need to survive with nothing stopping you. The raiders that attack your shelter just stop before getting through the front door if you upgrade it and the encounters that happen outside rarely have combat that kills you. All you need to do is make sure you keep enough of the building resources like metal stocked high and upgrade your workshop  instead of upgrading things like the water filter. As soon as you get a good backpack you can gather food to last you for days since you never seem to run out of water becuse it rains too much.

The game needs to become unforgiving and make resources rarer. If you are used to playing This War of Mine this game should be easier in comparison but both games have a small learning curve to the tricks to getting a self sustaining base.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Sheltered takes some flavors of This War of Mine and combines it with post-apocalyptic survivalism in pixel-styled art. While this game is early access, a large portion of the game are pretty well fleshed out, and will give you several hours of fun before reaching a end game lull in its current iteration.

There's definitely room for improvement, balance, and new elements of gameplay, but for any player who enjoys the survival-genre mood in games, this is definitely worth purchasing either now, or further down the road.

reviewText: I first reviewed this game in Early Access, hoping that it would be good by the time of release.  It was not ready to leave Early Access.  It is not ready to play, and it is absolutely not the deep and emotional survival management game" it is marketed to be.\n\nIt's not deep.  The challenge still comes down to three tasks - getting a water supply
recommended: and upgrading your expedition gear to maximize equipment income.  Once those are done
hoursPlayed: the rest of the 'risks' aren't challenges at all; the game boils down to building whatever you can make from your spare supplies
voteText: while everyone mills around at home.  Every so often
