reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you name all the characters as your family member's name then this game would be immersive. Also don't judge this game because it's pixely like because this game is very challanging and the mechanics are in depth. At this stage this game can last you about between 5-15 hours depending on your style of play but if you spent beyond those approximant hours playing then it would be repetitive due to the lack in elements as well as this is an unfinished game. Despite this is an early access game, its definitely worth your money to be immersed in this apocalyptic wasteland.

Everytime the situation will be different to prevent repetition.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Sheltered takes some flavors of This War of Mine and combines it with post-apocalyptic survivalism in pixel-styled art. While this game is early access, a large portion of the game are pretty well fleshed out, and will give you several hours of fun before reaching a end game lull in its current iteration.

There's definitely room for improvement, balance, and new elements of gameplay, but for any player who enjoys the survival-genre mood in games, this is definitely worth purchasing either now, or further down the road.

reviewText: This game is crazy amounts of fun. I followed this on Greenlight waiting for it to be released as the style of game is right up my alley. It definitely delivers on its promise, combining elements of The Sims with any number of post apocalyptic scavenger type games and a bit of FTL-ish rogue-like behavior and character progression. I dig the old school art style. The gameplay is engaging. Highly recommended.\n\nOne tip: don't go around recruiting everyone you see just because it sounds like fun. Make sure that you are prepared with enough supplies to house extra people.

reviewText: Sheltered is a game where you keep a family of four from the prospect of death in a post-apocalyptic world by running a nuclear bunker hence the name Sheltered. You can build and craft many things while exploring the fallout ridden world above foraging for items still left after the disaster before and expand your bunker with those newly found items. I would reccomend Sheltered to all who enjoy the post-apocalyptic theme, and to some who don't too. Over all, I very much enjoy the game Sheltered and I think you might too!

Early Access Review

the controls need some tweeking but besides that, thisisdefinately a nice little refresher game that offers a changeof paceina forgotten style , a definate must have for any rpg  fan and indeed any one that wants to survive the harsh realities of a post apocalyptic world!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is my favorite post-apocalypse survival / hoarding simulator to date! Mirroring games such as This War of Mine and even in the more distant past, the Oregon Trail series, Sheltered puts you in the position of moving your family into an underground bunker to toil through the days following the nuclear apocalypse. Even though in Early Access, this game offers a lot already and should hopefully prove to be even more promising as time goes on. Here's a quick run-down:

PROS
- A whole slew of resources to gather and use toward crafting and survival
- Many customization options, including expanding your shelter, placing many different craft stations, all the way down to painting the walls and adding some decor
- Frequent recruitment opportunities to turn your small family group into a formidable fighting force
- A few quests to enjoy - mainly gathering resources for desperate people or fighting off thugs who try to extort from you
- A fairly large map to explore
- An automation feature that lets your shelter dwellers go about their business and take care of their needs so you can pay attention to more important things
- Many aspects of your shelter to micromanage and tweak (great for the business/management gamers)
- A leveling system for your characters to increase their stats and become more invaluable to you
- Decent, turn-based fighting scenarios when your party encounters hostiles
- Active devs and frequent updates
- OK price at $15.00

CONS
- Some bugs, none of which are game breaking from what I've encountered, though annoying
- Not enough trading opportunities
- Questionable continuity or end game (as of now, you play forever without a conclusion)
- The camper van, which you painstakingly have to find parts for to make functional, will disappoint you by how inefficient it is to take on supply runs (guzzles more gas than it's worth)
- The stats Trauma" and "Stress" are thus far vague and hard to understand what triggers them and how to reduce these negative stats
- Somehow
date: everyone knows how to fix and build anything in your shelter
recommended:
even the kids. Negative points on realism (but how great would it be if we were all that mechanical - we'd all get some serious s**t done in our lives)
- Things in your shelter need fixed all the time - perhaps way more often than they should. This should be nerfed a little so it isn't a constant chore

SUGGESTIONS
- Add more quests or a main campaign storyline to make the game more compelling
- Have the camper van not chug so much gas to make it worth fixing
- Trade stations or more trading caravans coming to visit your shelter
- Shelter defense: How about having your group fend off occasional raids or adding in traps to keep your bunker safe?
- Additional maps
- More items to craft and even greater customization
- Automated shelter doors
hoursPlayed: so you don't have to always let your group members in manually\n- Include bios
voteText: a backstory
helpfulPercent: and greater stats customization of characters\n\nThus far
votesHelpful: the game has been strangely addictive and I look forward to more additions and polishing from the devs at Unicube and Team 17\n\nGrade: 8/10"

reviewText: It's been over a month now, and this control issue that was reported 4 ♥♥♥♥ING MONTHS AGO, has not only not been addressed in ANY WAY, but it has been completely ignored by this latest content update. Instead of fixing an issue that is keeping people who have bought the game from even playing it, at all, they've added more content that we cant play. Yay! Now they're is even more game I cant access. Would really love if my ability to use my hardware was a priority, but apparently I'm expected to buy a ♥♥♥♥ing gamepad so I can play this game I bought, since unlike every other friggin computer game, EVER, it cant use any other controls. Wish I could get a refund on this. I'd rather buy two packs of smokes then waste my money on this ♥♥♥♥. And I dont smoke. I'm demanding a refund on this game. I feel like I was sold an empty monopoly box, at least then I could've shaken the box to see if anything was in it. Here I was sold a start page with no game.\n\nIf your looking for a similar game, I highly reccommend Life In Bunker. That game is actually playable and I've had no issues with it myself. Sheltered? Havnt even played it yet after a month of trying and 4 months of the dev's not responding to a problem that prevents such action. Clearly they care more about the players they have yet to get, then the ones that have already bought the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played 4 hours of this game in one go. Made a family, and first thing I did was upgrade the crafting bench and then make tier 2 things because I watched some lps before buying. Things were rough due to starting out in the middle of nowhere with just a church near by, and my family spent days and days puking their guts out since it seems ALL OF OUR FOOD WAS BAD. Days went by with little water and food. After smartly letting some shmuckwith amazing stats join up I managed to find an entire town with a Florist, Petrol Station, and even a Pharmacy! Also that guy died and got eaten but that ain't important. Seroiusly, who cares?

So after a great haul I forced my son to upgrade things and made new things, so many things, like two new tier two water barrels and a sleeping bag. By then a woman named Debbie joined and proptly fell into a catatonic state for no reason.

Then more people joined and went on many adventures to bring my family back food and items for crafting, my loyal doge always cared for. These people also were ruthlessly eaten once they died because my god did they die for no reason. And everyone got sick from puking even after I made a stove. Luckily we rarely ran out of water as many upgrades were made to the of so vital systems that allowed us to survive in the wasteland.

Eventually I was allowed to be picky with what I grabbed. Yet nothing could have prepared me for my downfall, though it was invevitble, that sinister event.

Around day 30, after a long time of no water; Cynthia decided to become catatonic like Debbie who had been catatonic for so long she had been renamed SIS.

That was not the worst she had cursed us with. No. No that would be too kind. Throughout all of the trials and puking, despite all the hardships of managing so many people and not being able to go out due to no water; the wretched Cynthia had sat down right upon the single most important item! THE MOST VITAL ELEMENT OF MY FAMILY'S WELL BEING HAD BEEN OBSTURCTED FROM MY VIEW! I rashly decided to feed her and water her as much as possible in a bid to wake her from her terror.

But she never woke. She never got up. She sat like a shaking log in front of my dog's food bowl. At the 24th day, my doge began to whine and sit infront of her bowl. I could not click and give her food. Her health reached 46.

I looked at my upgraded systems, at my family, and my huge base. Bessie whined and I looked at my real life dog.

I saved and exited the game. 10/10 plan to make a new family soon.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Husband Journal:

It is day 1 of my family and I living in this shelter safe from the radiation that is on the surface. I know that I must somehow keep my family safe and support their need of food and water.
Days have passed and I spend my time scavenging all that I can to keep my family living comfortably. I was able to scavenge enough to build a trap and try to catch any animal that comes by. I go out and realize I forgot to put on my hazmat suit. I now have radiation poisoning. Without anti radiation pills, I knew that it would be a matter of time until my demise. I did not waste my time that I had remaining. I go out constantly scavenging until my death.

Wife Journal:
My husband is dead. Left me alone with me and the two kids. Because of his death, I had to be more careful. Constantly wearing the hazmat and crafting a gas mask for any runs. The mask soon run out. Food running low. So is water. I knew, I must sacrifice myself for the sake of my kids. I go on the surface, no mask or protection. Collecting plenty of food. before my final minutes are up, I run into a woman. Promise her shelter as long as she takes care of my kids. She agrees. Please god, be with them as I pass

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Enjoyed this for 9 hours. I'll probably play more when it's released.

Here are some ways I think the game could be altered to make it more enjoyable to a gamer like me:

My biggest complaint and the main reason I've stopped playing is the way items respawn at locations. Why take away from the realism. Respawn water after it rains, but no other items, unless it's to be implied that other survivors are leaving them there after your previous visit.

What is supposed to be the logic behind the inability to redirect my expeditions mid-journey? I can tell them to come home go home but nowhere else?

If the developers haven't played Neo Scavenger I recommend they do so. The same to anyone who likes the idea of this game. I specifically enjoy it's inventory system. Every item has a size, shape, and weight. Some may find it tedious and less appealing to casual gamers, but the realism it adds is worth it in my opinion. Unfortunatly it's loot respawning seems almost as unrealistic as this game's.

The ability to pause while managing survivors might provide more incentive to build a community. Sometimes  I turn down recruits because my hands are full directing my current population. The resource cost of additional survivors isn't worth it if I have no time to manage them.

I recruit a guy with a baseball bat and somehow he loses it on his way to the shelter? Was he also not carrying any food or water?

(Spoiler)
I stopped playing after 9 hours mainly because I didn't like the respawing loot system, and secondly because the major limiting factor for extended survival seemed to be making sure I could find enough ingredients to make gas masks (mainly plastic), which became boring. I'm not sure I approve of making gas masks being one time use. (How are gas masks so effective at preventing radiation poisoning anyway?) My strategy became the following: 1)Max out my water capacity (I got it up to 90 with 10 survivors). 2) Send a party of 2 carrying 80 water on a do-or-die mission to return with 2 gas masks or their equivalent in ingredients to allow for a future scavenging mission. They didn't make it. I decided to try to let them handle an encounter without my intervention, which apparently was a bad idea; One was killed. The second escaped, but soon suffered the same fate despite my guidance. In retrospect I guess I could have gone about things differently and been more successful, but I've lost interest in trying again.

Enjoyed the game. Worth the money. Make the loot respawning system more realistic or get rid of it entirely and I may play more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I couldn't bear to give this bad feedback as I like and support it. But right now it's a click-farm. Keep clicking, get resources, and buy upgrades that let you click more.

It's fast-developing, and the devs are listening to people - which is normally good. I'm certainly going to check back in again in a few weeks to see how it changes. What I think is going wrong at the moment is that they have taken away some things that the community said were frustrating. In the version I first played, my bunker-family spent ages waiting for rain, and when they were on their last legs it finally rained, but it was poison rain, so they had to wait for it to be slowly filtered while their health was creeping down. Drinking it would have risked radiation poisoning and using up virtually irreplacable meds. The parts to make gas masks were also so rare that I'd be left with choices like everyone can die of hunger, or we could dismantle the water supply so that somebody can make a mask and leave the bunker and find some food. Or maybe recruit somebody else that we can send on a suicide mission into the wasteland without a mask.

But since the last update, it rains all the time. I think I read that it rains at least once every 4 days. This predictability lets you gamble all the water on long foraging missions. Gas mask parts were a daft limiting factor (IRL you would only need to replace the filters not the whole mask), but now that they are more common it's like there is 1 limiting factor too few. Life is sustainable with the starting furniture, and it gets progressively easier.

I had a similar gripe with Fallout 3. Like in that game once you can recover health and reliably access uncontaminated water and food, half the thrill goes out of it.

Everyone always has an angle on what to do about stuff like this in early access games. They might add gangs or mutants to wear you down from outside, or they might change it round so you start with the good furniture and the game gradually wears it down, or they could give you bigger resource stockpiles and lower usage rates but make the replenishment very unpredictable, or they could put in a loyalty system so that when you add another person to the bunker they can forage for you, but they might also murder you in your bed. They could add in Sims-like interaction between the bunker people so that arguments and fights create some risk. Or they could make it that foraging gradually becomes harder as time passes after the initial fallout and food supplies decay, offset with the radiation/dust lessening.

A unique and odd aspect was you can customise the family. I like a lot of people based them on me, my wife and our kids. But I found that it made me want to not turn the game on if I knew they were all doing okay! It was like bunker family are okay
date: let's leave them be rather than logging on and risk watching them starve to death or having to eat the dog".\n\nClicking on people five times a day so they can drink

reviewText: For those who like simplistic strategy but addictive gameplay, this is likely the game for you. Considering my dislike of games without any real direction, it surprises me that I've already invested 100 hours into this game. I find myself wanting to build more and more things to try more approaches to survival, which will then keep me going even longer. If you are the type of person who likes the Civilization games, likes Fallout Shelter and/or doesn't mind a bit more of a casual experience, this game will certainly give you enjoyment.

reviewText: So I'm just gonna start off by saying, this game has been my life for the past week or so, and I reccomend it HEAVILY. I know right now it only says I have about 6 hours on record, but I usually play offline so in total it should be more like 25 hours on record. Sheltered is an amazing, difficult, strategy game that I can't get enough of. Usually with strategy games, they become boring after you've played them for a long time and it's the same thing over and over, but that is not the case with sheltered. Usually, every single shelter/family you create, you last longer than your last shelter/family. The two bad things I would say about this game is that it is very glitchy, and the controls are kind of weird at first, so it may take some time to get used to.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

your shelter is only big enough to accommodate one bed initially since you need to make a shower and a toilet etc. there's no room for anything else and you cant expand the shelter unless you have concrete, which i never seem to find ingredients for

water is definitely the bottleneck resource since you need it for showers, toilets, drinking, expeditions. you run out of it extremely fast and you find very little on expeditions so i guess you need rainfall to collect more. except it never seems to rain

the worst part of this game is that the characters are so god damn demanding, everyone gets tired and thirsty and needs to shower and ♥♥♥♥ way too often. there's only one bed so you are constantly cycling people through it  while everyone else gets stressed out and whines about how they have to sleep.

everyone seems to want to crap and shower way too often, which burns through your water. are you supposed to minmax this and force people to just be unhappy or something? because realistically keeping people hygienic means they're going to waste all your water

by day 4 my crew is already starting to be traumatized because they're a bunch of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who need to sleep and poop and shower every 5 seconds. i managed to go out on a really simple expedition to a nearby farm and wasted most of my water doing that so now everyone is dying of thirst too.

i like resource management but this is just masochism. it's like playing the sims except your sims are neurotic and always stressing out and throwing tantrums no matter what you do

reviewText:
Sigh. This is one of those games that sounds like such a cool idea on paper, but the way it's done here doesn't really bring it to life.

The basic premise is good. Imagine FTL, but you're trying to stay alive in a bomb shelter. That should be amazing, right? The catch is that the game should be difficult, and Sheltered is not a difficult game by any stretch. In FTL, you have a goal you need to build up for: the flagship. That game would be substantially less interesting if A: the random encounters were all easy, and B: there was no flagship.

In the beginning, there are certain things you have to build for your shelter, mostly for storage, but once you've got those down, the game becomes too easy. Supplies are simply too plentiful, and they replenish in the places you scavenge, so as long as you can hold everything you've found, you're golden. In all my playthroughs, I never ran out of food, and once I learned to build a lot of water storage, I never ran out of water.

You could up the difficulty by getting all the shelter upgrades and then putting 14 people in your shelter, but you don't need them. I didn't need the 7 or 8 that I had as it was, because just keeping up with maintenance and construction only requires 2 or 3 at absolute maximum. The fact that the children you start with can help out so well is kinda broken; basically, just give them a welding torch, and they can fix your water filter.

You would think that going into the post-apocalyptic wasteland would be a dangerous proposition, but it's not. The very hardest encounters will feature people with guns, but for most of the game, the people you fight are a cinch to beat. Frequently, they're unarmed. Here's how: 2 people with 7+ strength, each with handaxes, and kevlar if you feel like being careful. You'll find kevlar and axes all the time, and what you'll get is a two-man death squad that chews up the worst the wasteland can throw at you, and spit it back out like a paper spitball. Then, on top of that, there are guns and grenades. Basically, if you do a bit of scavenging, and then bother to arm your people, you've got it locked down.

For a while, maxing out your shelter will be kinda fun, and there is some satisfaction in getting the best stuff, but the difficulty scales so minimally that it doesn't actually matter. The shelter raids were a source of complaint a while back because your people can't fight back (yes, that death squad I mentioned above can only fight if they're out in the wasteland, not if they're defending their children from murder cultists), so all you could do is set traps. But that was useful at least in presenting a threat to players, something you had to prepare for.

Above all, there's no real end game. You can try and survive as long as you want, but that gets to be boring after about day 10 because it's never actually difficult to begin with, and if you're bothering to get upgrades, nothing you find will set you back.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

awesome survival game. the home life is the struggle... however, the combat is insanely broken at the moment... pretty much game ruining and unplayable...

for the first couple days youll fight people with humble stats, after that you fight strictly courageous people that will do 50+ damage 3 hits in a row and pretty much instantly kill ANYBODY you have... including people with guns...

it was kinda funny, pretty much every time i equip a bag for extra loot room, within the next expedition serial killer clark comes out of no where and destroys face... hes even wiped two of my people with guns, while he had a lead pipe... and i missed 4 shotgun blasts on turn one!! (i didnt even know you could shoot more than once in one turn, that was the last of my ammo anyways haha)


anyways... in conclusion... i REALLY like this game... it WILL be a fun game at some point, for now it will only lead to hair pulling as no amount of time or skill in this game will allow you to beat clark the serial killing maniac who has courageous trait and will do 150+ damage every turn.

for now i give it the not recommended... this might not sit well with some, but IMO i judge the game for what it is not what it will be...., after what happened to starbound, and their devs started 50 projects with the money they got from starbound early access.. never ended up finishing starbound... or even make progress...

i hope you guys will fix combat, ive heard snippets from people saying you are working on an overhaul. i would love to change my review when you have changed the game breaking errors :) well done so far though.


TL:DR combat severely unfair/broken. base life is awesome everything else is awesome but vote no until combat is actually playable... (no clarks doing 150 damage per hit, when my people with comparable stats do 1-5 damage with rebar or miss 4 shots in one turn with a.. shotgun) i hope those were slugs and not buckshot ><

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First of all, I currently kinda like this game, BUT;

The first time I played it, it was apparent that it was riddled with poor design decisions. First of all, in order to get anything out of your raids, you HAVE to, get this, HAVE to, answer the radio calls. If you do not, they won't bring ANYTHING back. Now, it seems to me as if it wouldn't be a big deal to put in a randomizer that picks out some stuff based on your current needs, so why haven't they done that? The tutorial in itself is laughably bad and tells you almost nothing. And they only sometimes warn you when a radio transmission is incoming, otherwise you have no choice but to pay close attention to the radio.

Secondly, my big strong survivor, who with his trusty dog and axe had taken down many a bear, sat down with his arms around his head and just rocked back and forth crying please don't hurt us, when two women raided my shelter! In what world does that compute? The fact that you aren't given the option to defend your precious possesions just because you're inside the shelter, when there are plenty of weapons lying around, is just ludicrious. Will it make traps obsolete, myeh, pretty much, but there are better ways of balancing things than to make them completely illogical.

Fix those issues and this'll turn into a thumbs up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After playing two hours, I thought the game was on a great path, and I was terrible at surviving. One more hour, and two more games later, and I'm in love. I still suck at surviving, though.

Sheltered is a $14.99(As of release) post apocalyptic game where you choose four members of a family (2 parents which can be the same sex, and two siblings, which of course, can be of the same sex) and make a go at surviving difficulties such as sparse food, contaminated water, fallout, and yes, even other survivors. Do not fear too much, though. Most survivors you come upon are friendly, and you can even recruit outsiders to work alongside you in your shelter! But don't get so eager. Food is hard to find. Food keeps your survivors energized. They NEED it. They WILL die without it, along with water. You must make every decision carefully as one wrong click can turn a good day into the worst. Should I talk to these strangers or try to sneak away? They may have good stuff

reviewText:
Summary:Numerous reveiwers have compared this game to FTL: Faster Than Light. Oh if only this were true! FTL is a true gem of a game, with balanced gameplay and eliciting a constant feeling of imminent peril. It is perhaps the best game ever created.

Sheltered is a micromange-heavy grindfest entirely lacking balance. If you can survive the first week or two (which is essentially just a case of storing enough water, and not doing anything really stupid like walking outside without a hazmat suit) it quickly becomes a case of grinding for items without any sense of danger. Admittedly this may not be the case if you select more-balanced attributes for your family, unfortunately I seem to have stumbled upon the over-powered traits almost immediately.

But there remains hope. There are the makings of a good game here. With just a little work (better balance, more varied content) Sheltered could become a good game. Implementing some sort of long-term effect for the morality choices made by the player could also be very interesting. But as it is, Sheltered does not feel ready for release.

Key critical issues appear below.

Micromanagement:Most of your time is spent micro-managing your survivors: every task except stat restoration must be manually initiated - repairs, training, crafting, tending plants, etc. Even taking medicine or using bandages requires user input. (I have lost count of the number of times an ill or injured family member has died simply because I did not see their negative status, given this mechanic). With small numbers of survivors this microing gets tedious; with larger numbers I expect it becomes impossible. This could be fixed either by improving the automate mechanic to automate these tasks as well, or by allowing the player to instruct a survivor to continually perform a certain type of task whenever they do not have needs to take care of.

Another big time-sink is inventory management, trying to maximise the items you bring home or purchase in a trade due to limited storage space. This could be improved by adding a colour-coding scheme for inventory management, e.g. colouring the background of an object green if it will take an empty inventory slot, yellow if it will be added to an inventory slot already containing other objects of the same type, and red if there will be no space in the inventory.

Grinding:With strong characters (easily achievable - see balance below) exploring the world is just a case of grinding without thinking: search every location, fight every encounter (at least, those the game lets you - I want the option to kill traders and would-be recruits - in fact anybody!), with no risk to your survivors.

Combat balance:With strong characters, the different options available in combat are rarely required; simply melee each enemy in turn, or empty your clip into them once you have firearms. Steal, subdue, defend all seem underpowered. The early game may require a little caution (just in case you end up outnumbered) and the late game may be very different - I have no idea, I got bored of the grindy mid-game.

As for getting strong characters, this is also far too easy: simply select Courageous and Troubled for any character you wish to send on expeditions and send them out in pairs, as this will give them two guaranteed (and a third very likely) high-power hits each - none shall stand against this.

Invasions?:In about 32 hours of gameplay and reaching somewhere around day 150, I only suffered one attempted invasion so I cannot even judge this part of the game. However, I did find that the attacker failed to even make it past my two un-upgraded doors...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Sorry to say this but, I don't recommended this game for anybody who would have the same taste as me (who like slower-paced game and have character development styled game play).


This game is like This War of Mine on steriod. The goal isn't to create a badass Vault Dweller like Fallout, or a legendary road warrior like Mad Max, but to survive while micromanaging every basic daily task there is.

COMBAT IS NEVER A MAJOR PART OF THE GAME, DAILY SURVIVAL IS.

People who's a hardcoregamer, hyperactive, and like everyday life survival game will like this game. I can see that.

But if you're looking for an action packed wastland adventure game with slow-paced  safe sanctuary management you will not find it here.

Again, this is NOT Fallout, this is This War of Mine on steriod.

This game is nice for killing time, it is fun but really does need a lot of further improvement.

Things that need to be improved on
- Combat! Doesn't seems right that I am not able to flee and ended up getting 1 hit ko by some random dude or lady.
- Some essential items are impossible to find, I can't seems to survive more than 30 days as plastics are hard to come by and i won't be able to craft mask to explore for resources. (Why not just let me wear that yellow suit and explore)
- Pet dies way too easily, should be able to adopt a new pet out in the wild
-Crafting and Upgrading, erm same issue as plastics i can't find much hinge at all hence i can't upgrade my work space to unlock tier 2 items. :(
- Food poisoning is irritating, at least let me choose to be healed by medication

Alright enough of my ranting, in summary the game is in need to balance the overall game combat, crafting, items, exploration. I felt that this game has got huge potential so just keep improving and I am sure it will be a fantastic game. So to all people please continue to support this game so that the developer can improve the overall gameplay, cheers!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I came into this game with some mixed feelings. I had seen a bit of gameplay on YouTube, and it sparked my interest, but it is all too easy to be enticed into a game while watching others play it then realize that you don't enjoy it personally when you actually buy it. This game did not disappoint.

It is not as slow as it would seem. You move from problem to problem without relent. There is always something that needs done, and these issues require well-thought-out solutions. You are running low on food and water. Do you send out an expedition in hopes of finding food? Do you expend that water for the chance? Do you got to a place that you looted a while ago in hopes that passing people have left things in the house for less water or do you use a lot of water to search new areas and have a chance of finding a lot or nothing at all? This is not even the tip of the iceburg. It is a much deeper experience than one would think if you put thought into your gameplay.

How long can you last? After all, family does come first.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Sorry to say this but, I don't recommended this game for anybody who would have the same taste as me (who like slower-paced game and have character development styled game play).


This game is like This War of Mine on steriod. The goal isn't to create a badass Vault Dweller like Fallout, or a legendary road warrior like Mad Max, but to survive while micromanaging every basic daily task there is.

COMBAT IS NEVER A MAJOR PART OF THE GAME, DAILY SURVIVAL IS.

People who's a hardcoregamer, hyperactive, and like everyday life survival game will like this game. I can see that.

But if you're looking for an action packed wastland adventure game with slow-paced  safe sanctuary management you will not find it here.

Again, this is NOT Fallout, this is This War of Mine on steriod.

reviewText:
Summary:Numerous reveiwers have compared this game to FTL: Faster Than Light. Oh if only this were true! FTL is a true gem of a game, with balanced gameplay and eliciting a constant feeling of imminent peril. It is perhaps the best game ever created.

Sheltered is a micromange-heavy grindfest entirely lacking balance. If you can survive the first week or two (which is essentially just a case of storing enough water, and not doing anything really stupid like walking outside without a hazmat suit) it quickly becomes a case of grinding for items without any sense of danger. Admittedly this may not be the case if you select more-balanced attributes for your family, unfortunately I seem to have stumbled upon the over-powered traits almost immediately.

But there remains hope. There are the makings of a good game here. With just a little work (better balance, more varied content) Sheltered could become a good game. Implementing some sort of long-term effect for the morality choices made by the player could also be very interesting. But as it is, Sheltered does not feel ready for release.

Key critical issues appear below.

Micromanagement:Most of your time is spent micro-managing your survivors: every task except stat restoration must be manually initiated - repairs, training, crafting, tending plants, etc. Even taking medicine or using bandages requires user input. (I have lost count of the number of times an ill or injured family member has died simply because I did not see their negative status, given this mechanic). With small numbers of survivors this microing gets tedious; with larger numbers I expect it becomes impossible. This could be fixed either by improving the automate mechanic to automate these tasks as well, or by allowing the player to instruct a survivor to continually perform a certain type of task whenever they do not have needs to take care of.

Another big time-sink is inventory management, trying to maximise the items you bring home or purchase in a trade due to limited storage space. This could be improved by adding a colour-coding scheme for inventory management, e.g. colouring the background of an object green if it will take an empty inventory slot, yellow if it will be added to an inventory slot already containing other objects of the same type, and red if there will be no space in the inventory.

Grinding:With strong characters (easily achievable - see balance below) exploring the world is just a case of grinding without thinking: search every location, fight every encounter (at least, those the game lets you - I want the option to kill traders and would-be recruits - in fact anybody!), with no risk to your survivors.

Combat balance:With strong characters, the different options available in combat are rarely required; simply melee each enemy in turn, or empty your clip into them once you have firearms. Steal, subdue, defend all seem underpowered. The early game may require a little caution (just in case you end up outnumbered) and the late game may be very different - I have no idea, I got bored of the grindy mid-game.

As for getting strong characters, this is also far too easy: simply select Courageous and Troubled for any character you wish to send on expeditions and send them out in pairs, as this will give them two guaranteed (and a third very likely) high-power hits each - none shall stand against this.

Invasions?:In about 32 hours of gameplay and reaching somewhere around day 150, I only suffered one attempted invasion so I cannot even judge this part of the game. However, I did find that the attacker failed to even make it past my two un-upgraded doors...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Sheltered is an amazing game.  It is a more personal take on Bethesda's Fallout Shelter.  You start with a family and you really start to care about what happens to them.  They will die, it will be sad, but you will go on.

The crafting is excellent.  I really like the latter stage crafting.  There are lots of neat blueprints and an RV you can repair so you can get around the wasteland more quickly.

However, there be bugs here.  I hit one that cost me all progress I made in an entire game but, this is still one of the coolest games I've played this year and I will play it again.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWas very excited when i came across this game. it had an interesting premise. One of my friends raved about this game, and recommended i play it. However, i regret the purchase. the tutorial does not explain anything, the gameplay is boring, and i fail to find any redeeming qualities. reviewText:
Gives a tantalising illusion of depth, but is in reality dissapointingly simple. Its like playing an even more depressing version of the Sims; a game which will test your patience and devotion to emotionless stick figure characters, rathen than any skill. Team 17 have made something similar with The Escapists- a game which had such incredible promise in concept, but quickly reveals itself to be a monotonous endurance test.

This is not to say that there is nothing in the game that I liked. The art style is effectively depressing and dim, the overall mechanics are solid- but there just isnt enough meat on the bones on this one to keep you going for any longer than the 20th in game day.

Get Fallout Shelter instead- its much better made and best of all, it's free.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Your people won't be able to manage even very basic needs without you telling them to. You can auto a lot of stuff but then they'll start to drink water that'll kill them. It's not possible to automate maintenance nor is it possible to tell people to open and close the main entry or done the protective suits required if you don't want to die from radioactive fallout when you leave. Combat is boring at best.

Officially this is still early access so things might shape up. The comments on the forum from the developers leave a different impression however -- they usually talk about the game as if it's more or less done.

I haven't encountered any bugs (that I've noticed) but the game is so lacking in features and requires so much attention to detail that it just becomes boring.
voteText: 29 of 61 people (48%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I couldn't play this game for more than an hour despite my love of post apacolyptic survival games.

Starting with the options menu:
There is almost no options menu excluding some music and SFX adjustment bars that don't do much and a resolution selector there isn't much here. This isn't much of an issue except... You can't change the keybinds at all. While this isn't a huge issue it is a bit inconvenient.

Moving on to character creation:
It's alright nothing special, nothing worth mentioning. I really do not like the fact that you CANNOT set your own stats instead you have to use presets which are mostly heavily one sided towards a specific skill.

Gameplay:

Tutorial- the tutorial really needs a big overhaul to cover the controls, objectives, how to feed and shower your characters and pretty much anything you would need to know to play.

Goals and Direction- The game while not linear in any way does a very poor job in guiding you to do anything at all, it's a lot of micromanagment and a lot of unexplained stuff that you have to just guess at. Playing this for the first hour may leave you frustrated.

Overall- Overall excluding all the issues the gameplay is pretty straight forward. Your goal is to survive that is it so good luck.

Conclusion:
I didn't enjoy this game at all and unfortunately I think this game will need a lot of work to be worth the price. Yes it's only $15 but I've seen a lot of other games that may warrant your $15 more so than this. This is only my opinion though and maybe I'm being a bit hard on this game, but the issues I'm posing are still real issues that need addressing and I believe the developer should consider overhauling a large portion of the game and make it easier for the player to actually interact with and explore the world. As of now I feel that my time is spent better with Bethesda's Fallout Shelter.

Thank you for reading and again this is just my opinion :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really like survival games like this and this has a lot of potential. Exploring the map looks like a lot of fun. However, there are some major issues that keep me from recommending it.

Biggest flaw is the user experience. Controlling the characters is a pain. If you have characters with the same hair color, it's very confusing to tell who is currently selected because everyone more or less looks the same in the portrait. You can click to move the person to that location, but if you want to move them again you have to cancel their current action in their queue. I mis-clicked so many times just trying to figure out this system. I felt out of control over characters that needed CONSTANT MICROMANAGING. Thankfully, there is an auto feature that lets residents take care of their needs, but just selecting someone was such a pain. But if I need to be selecting these people a lot, selecting them should be much, much easier.

One of the central challenges of the game is that your equipment breaks down over time, and quickly. But none of it repairs quickly. So most of your time is spent repairing things, which is to say, you have someone stand there for hours. No challenge to it, it's just annoying. I spent more time watching a loading bar fill than worrying about food or water. Not how a survival game should be.

It has great art, a good premise, clearly a lot of love and time went into it. I did enjoy my playthrough, I just can't see myself ever playing it more.

reviewText:
Simply an amazing game!

DO NOT be fooled by it's seemingly simplistic art style; it's a relatively complex game, with a lot going on and to be managed. I've been able to plough through hours on end simply because the game never leaves you without an urgent task to perform, and it is extremely well balanced.

My favourite aspect is probably the fact that you don't need the same survivors that you start the game with to continue playing, because providing there are still survivors (even if they're relatively new) the story continues with them.

Strongly, strongly reccomend if you enjoy indie games, survival games, management games, retro games, simulation games... Totally worth the tiny price!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR: This game shows a lot of promise but it has a long way to go before it is finished.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I was one of the Kickstarter backers and I was really excited about this game and have eagerly been watching the updates. I still am excited about this game but in it's current state I cannot reccomend it. There is a ton of promise but right now there are too many things that need to be fixed. Still, this is an alpha release so hopefully, with some community feedback, all of these problems will be addressed for the final release. I'll of course update this review as the game is updated.

Pros:
- Beautiful astetics and pixel art

Cons:
- Tutorial does not teach the game. The learning curve is far too steep making the game frustrating and confusing to play
- Unintuitive controls. This is a mouse driven game... but the mouse does different things in different menus? Sometimes you need to right click, sometimes left click and it's seldom clear what is what...
- Bugs. There are bugs especially if you run the game full screen. The click boxes on the menu screen does not scale with resolution.
- Boring gameplay. It may be due to lack of features but the gameplay right now is rather boring and repetitive.
- Hidden Mechanics. It is very hard to determine the mechanics of the game so strategic playing is not possible. For instance, if you don't run the generator your water isn't filtered. That makes sense but there's no indication in the game that water and power are linked. I had to determine that through trial and error.
- Features are missing. Some things  promised in the Kickstarter (or shown in the Kickstarter) have not et been added and it's unknown if they will be added in the future.

reviewText:
Did both of the parents in my family die of radiation exposure?
Yes
Did the children watch as those bodies of the dead were harvested for meat due to a shortage of buriel supplies?
Errm....yes
Did the son then die tragecly to a wandering bear in the wildness?
Yes, but seriously that wasnt my fault!
Does the surviving 10 year old girl now lead a team of survivors in this post apocalyptic wasteland, and does she have a thirst for blood?
Yes!

I kickstarted this game (in 2014?), and although not as good as I was hoping, Sheltered is a decent game for the price being asked. Admitadly in my 10 hours or so play I feel like Ive got my fill, and seen most of what the game has to offer. Once you get the hang of the games mechanics, its does feel like its get very easy, especially compared to slightly similiar concepts like Zafehouse Diaries. You send your team out, find supplies, ungrade your Shelter, and repeat.

If your looking for something that will be provide you with hours of replayability, I would perhaps give this a miss. If you want a fun 10-15 hour experience, Sheltereds not a bad way to spend your money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game could be good, but as it stands right now its just not worth it.

While the overall concept seems like it will be good, take your family and survive, far too much is stacked against you to make the game fun.

Run out of Anti-rad meds, your family will die from radiation poisoning. Don't have a pair of strong combatants? At some point while scavaging you will be killed. Don't have the resources to upgrade your shelter? You'll run out of food/air/water very quickly.

Theres just alot of balence issue that make the game more of a grind then a challenge. While I don't mind challenging, having to wait for it to rain and hope its not 'black rain' to get a reliable water source is not fun. Nore is needing to don a hazmat suit every time I need to go topside to repair the air or water filter and build snare traps for food.

The game tries to be realistic, but fails on balence of events and fun. My first attempt my survivours got radition poisoning on their first scavenge, while those that stayed home got food poisoning.

As it stands right now, its only really worth it if you buy while on sale and enjoy the survival game genre. Otherwise, not worth your money as it currently stands.

The Free Fallout Shelter game on mobile does this type of gameplay much better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the game Fallout Shelter wishes it was (if it didn't rake in millions of dollars in its current form).

Pros / Good stuff
+ A lot like This War of Mine, except more involved with more upgrades / items. If you liked that game this one is very easily reccomended.
+ Basically a better all round version of FO: Shelter, except no p2w or timers (unless you run out of gas masks / pills, see below).
+ Plenty to craft, upgrade and do in game even in early access. Lots of addictive fun moment to moment in a tycoon/survival game way.
+ Updates are frequent enough to make most of the cons below a non issue going forward.
+ Graphics are charming and get the job done. Painting the shelter is a nice touch.

Cons / Balance issues
- U.I needs some love. Bare bones tutorial and in game tool tips/descriptions. Controls can be fiddly at first. There's a guide in the steam community that helped a lot. One way or the other, this will always be an alt-tab-to-wiki type game.
- If you run out of gas masks & rad pills its more or less gg (except not, its bg), unless you eat people or trade/craft for masks/plastic/pills which can take many in game days of holding down shift and checking the whiteboard to fix stuff.
- Funny crafting/looting balance (this is early access version). You need too many nails for everything and you're lucky if you find 1 in a lumber yard of all places. You need little cement for 1 thing yet find cement/sand/limestone in bulk everywhere. Shouldn't need nails to install a toilet, should use cement etc etc.
- Combat is currently RNG ♥♥♥♥♥, thus far I haven't gotten a high dex character to successfully run away from combat. You can mitigate the RNG in ways but its a far cry from something like neo-scavenger.

In all, its worth the asking price if you like tycoon/management games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Nice game but bad graphics.
I know, I am sure it is cool and groovy for you young kids to play a game with 'retro' graphics.
But as someone actually old enough to remember the 1980s and 1990s, it is real hard to enjoy a game when it looks like games used to look when our computers couldn't do any better.

Anyway, the game itself is pretty decent and a few hours of enjoyment but I myself couldn't get past the graphics.
I guess I'm shallow.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI bought this game because I love realistic post-apocalyptic stuff and micromanaging that includes building, logistical thinking and taking care of people. Sheltered has all of those things. I am a big fan of This War of Mine" and
hoursPlayed: which this game strongly reminds me of - in a good way. It's not like a rip-off
voteText: but more like a strongly improved version with its own features and art style. Speaking of that
helpfulPercent: the art style
votesHelpful: of course
votesTotal: is rather "special" and I was required to get used to it first
votesFunny: because I don't like minecraftish pixel graphics. But within the first 15 minutes of the game I already began to like it.\n\nNow
commentsCount: the first and most important feature about this game (besides the fact that it's pretty much the only one of its kind)
column16: is its realism. The building feels realistic (there are tons of different lootable resources which are required for the several in-game structures)
column17: the people's needs are realistic (water
column18: food
column23: but based on locations (such as scrap yards having lots of metal or gas staions having lots of fuel)...\n\nThe second great feature is the difficulty. I restarted at least 10 times until I finally understood what I need to do
column24: which structures are the most important ones
column25: how I keep everyone alive... there is radiation
column26: there are fights during your scavenge runs
column27: there are raids and fires and
column28: the scariest thing of them all: there is hunger. And it's really challenging to handle all this at once. In fact
column29: there are already so many features
column30: that some developers would have already sold it as a finished product. But this is Early Access. And the devs keep us updated and even answer in the forums. I can only imagine what great things are going to be added yet.\n\nThe only not-so-good thing is the fact
column31: that the endgame is quite limited yet. The shelter is limited to 3 floors and you can't keep more than 14 people at once (otherwise the oxygen level will be not sufficient)
column32: and once you have built everything
column33: it will become a little uninteresting. It took me 16 hours to get to this point. But the good thing is
column34: that all locations are randomized every time
column35: so you could just start a new game.\n\nIn short: this game is a very great and unique post-apocalyptic shelter management game with a high focus on realism and tons of potential. I'd say that this game in it's current state is already easily worth the price they ask for
column36: and once they have added all planned features
column37: this is going to be totally awesome."

reviewText:
OK, This piece of crap is TOTALY BROKEN!

I can live with bugs and glitches, I had alot of fun in several Early Access games.

BUT THIS GAME ISN'T EARLY ACCESS!!

I was at 100+ days, everything was good, base was ok and had enough supllies, until:

My base got raided. I got 4 shotgun traps, all armed. I hid my kid behind a fake wall (WHERE SHE SHOULD HAVE BEEN SAFE!). Raiders broke through the doors, guess what happened:

1. my kid (who was hidden a floor down) got into a fight with raiders BEFORE the passed the traps, alone. She killed one but the second one she couldn't handle. Worst of all, the raiders were invisible so I could not see what weapon they had. You cannot run from these fights, you can only defend or attack, until you die. If you happen to kill 1 raider, you will have to battle the next and so on. You also CANNOT choose who they battle.

2. Someone else from my team then had to fight, in these fights you cannot run and you have to fight. Even if you win that fight, you have to battle the next and the next until you're dead. Another one killed by an invisible raider.

3. Then dad had to fight. What was pretty strange, CAUSE HE WAS OUT ON AN EXPEDITION MILES AWAY!!!

4. Ok, killed the raiders so I'm done now? NO! SOMEHOW THE SAME RAIDERS I JUST KILLED AND WHO KILLED 2 OF MY TEAM HAVE WOKEN UP FROM THE DEAD! Yea, the woke up from the dead, trashing my place, take 1 food and go on their merry way. Really? WHAT THE ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥!

I don't normaly ragequit on games. Even not on bugged poorly Early Access.

BUT THIS AINT EARLY ACCESS AS IT SHOULD HAVE BEEN!!!

DEV'S FIX UR ♥♥♥♥ OR FIX YOUR PRICETAG!!!

You cannot expect people to pay for games with gamebreaking bugs and glitches in where they loose just because your game-mechanics are BROKEN!!!

Do not buy this piece of trash, this should have been in early access at best!

God I'm ♥♥♥♥♥♥!

0/10 Piece of trash



EDIT: I will rewrite my review when this Base Raid" mechanic is fixed!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!

The largest issue: you cannot change characters for missions. This means you will always have to send your primary adult (first character) on a mission first otherwise you cant send anyone. Then after that it goes down the oldest character list for who goes next. Additionally your 'party size' will ALWAYS be 1, because there is no means to add a second person into the party. By the way, just because you completed a mission doesnt mean your loot will stay. When you transfer it you run the risk of it being deposited into some unaccessable infinite void instead of your storage.

I fail to understand how Steam keeps 'Green Lighting' games that are far beyond even pre-alpha stage and flooding the marketplace with game content that is little more than a title screen and deceptive trailer.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Would get radiation posioning and die to be eaten again to save my starving family...

13/10

It is a mix of This War of Mine, FTL, The Sims, and Fallout. You need to keep an eye on all your survivors and their needs constantly. Make sure they eat, drink, sleep, shower and use the toilet. They dont do anything on their own until it is too late. If you neglect them they tend to go catitonic and or will die. Permideath is real in this game, while you can recruit others into your shelter.... Once your family dies the game ends.

Crafting is fun and a huge part of this game becasue you only start with a basic shelter and need beds, shower, toilet, stove, storage, and expantions to your shelter to keep your family happy and alive. Exploring in the early stages can be rough but is something you must do to stay alive. You got to make the choice of do you carry something to trade with or do you go empty handed so you can grab more loot.

The game is in its early stages and it is wonderful! I can wait to see what else they add to it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 15: I finally accepted a stranger into the shelter. He seemed fine at first, but he was freaking out way too much about some minor water issues. It got to a point where I sent him outside without a radiation suit to die, but then it rained so I let him come back, and he calmed down.

How many days can YOU last??

It's early access, so if you want a 'perfect' game, you should wait before you buy. Searching for all developer posts on the steam discussion forum helps to understand everything better. Documentation will be added and bugs will be solved with time. I'm having a lot of fun! The developers are quite active on the steam discussion forum, there's a 'report a problem' sub-forum for bugs. I'll be keeping a close eye on the steam update history page for the patch notes, it only gets better from here!!

reviewText:
After suffocating, starving, poisoning, dehydrating and sending my first few familys to the old knife to a gun fight, where the knifedidn't stand a chance (RIP Lucy and Brucy)
I think I've finally got a handle on things, the whole feeding and giving them water does make more sense now.

My advice;
Rush advancements on your work bench
Get those snares and freezer set up
Gather a lot of water
MAKE USE OF TRADE! Your water and meat can be used to buy a lot of trade goods

And all in all, don't bring a knife to a gun fight, or young crippled children that had awful stats.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIt has the potential to be a great game, but the camera control was very  janky for me; it's supposed to scroll when I move my mouse to the edge of the screen but it's hit or miss what speed it scrolls at to the point where I feel like the game does what it pleases. Sometimes it wouldn't even scroll the view at all! I found myself wrestling with the camera more often than actually getting things done. This would perhaps not be a dealbreaker on its own, but it exasperates the fact that the game's interface is naturally more fiddly than it has to be. As a result I just couldn't continue beyond the first hour.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The reliance on the RNG to be on your side is very high. Prepare to start over quite a few times through circumstances you can't avoid.

You need to be lucky enough to find the right material in the right amounts, while hoping that nothing bad happens to anyone.

Rain can be very unpredicatble. Some times you can wait days and only receive enough to fill 20 or 30 water even with an upgraded filter. This can leave you unable to leave your shelter to continue to collect other items leading to a spiral of defeat.

Sometimes you get random people that join you beyond your starting family of 4. These people will do absolutely nothing but consume resources for at least 20-30 minutes of real time. After an eternity of waiting on them to eat and drink their bloody fill, they'll finally go on expeditions. Once you run out of gas masks, and if they get radiation sickness, then you have 2 options. Use the pills or let them die. If you kick them out of the shelter before they die, they get angry and ruin your buildings.

You can get attacked by bandits and at the point of this writing, you cannot do anything except hide from them.

You can build Hiding Spots. It can be difficult to find enough hinges for every person you have.

All the items you need to be more efficient come at workbench level 3 and 4 and it can be quite tough to get to that point.

In this, you're relying on a lot of RNG, and not all that much strategy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have had a  very plesent experience playing this game. Bugs are minimal. There is enough for you to be busy doing for at least as long as I have played.

Looking forward to the following features that will make this game a gem to play:
1. The combat system rework (Check!)
2. A graphical rework, either to make it a high-end detailed retro style or realistic lifelike detail.
3. Achievements!
4. A story/quest system. (the game is completely survival based for now) (Half-check, no campaign or story but quests available.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is pretty great. It gives you a true suvival experience where food and water is always an issue. People will die, you will eat them.

It seems similar to fallout shelter at first glance, but really is not like it. Fallout Shelter is all about constant progression, its not a challenging game just a fun one. This game proves to be difficult and remain that way. You will make many morale decisions and is not for the lighthearted. The main thing I liked about this game was you ARE constantly progressing and unlocking things, but basic survival always remains an issue, it doesnt get to the point where you have a massive stock and its never a concern (at least not for a while)

Pros:
- Challenging, and remains that way.
- Very dark, it feels realistic for a survival game
- Somewhat detailed

Cons:
- Interaction between characters is mostly nonexistent, people don't argue or fall in love or question your morale decisions
- Combat is stale, random events seem to end roughly the same. Run, recuit, or trade. Ive never died from combat and I've seeked it out frequently
- Other than food/water your base is safe. No random attacks or traders trying to trick you
- People you recuit ACT like they might try to return and raid your vault, but they never attempt to decieve you
- Managing people can be annoying when you have a lot, telling them to do EVERY basic action from sleeping to using the bathroom. I understand letting them do it freely could waste resources, but a feature could be added to mark toilets to free use" or something where people auto use them whent he bar fills up


Overall
date: the survival aspects are very solid. Other than some slightly clunyky controls
recommended: the biggest drawback is the lack of ionteraction between players. It would be nice to have to analyze what people say and determine if they are trustworthy

reviewText:
Great game that got me hooked immediately and I recommend buying it now - v1.0 straight out of early access. I am very excited to see it develop over time (and hope it will).

The atmosphere and mechanics are great, permadeath deletes your save slot, the genre is a combination of the sims and cannibalism in 2d. You craft the familiar crop of gear, furniture and traps for your family's survival, alongside some cool machinery for your fort like a recycling plant and an indoor plant nursery. People offer to join your fort or attack you in the wilderness, and you can choose to confront or try to escape tough situations.

BONUS 1: the wood and pipe resources are also weapons
BONUS 2: family members drag bodies outside and bury them

The obvious things to expect in terms of improvements in the coming versions are probably the RPG and encounter depth, the combat system and maybe tweaks to control of the survivors' daily life. It seems like the gear is well balanced, except for the fuel system. There's too much fuel in the game, the generator uses very little, and the unit price is high. This tiny flaw along with the high price of records, bears and tools, makes the money aspect of trading less interesting. Instead, the availability of goods dictates the progress in certain stages, which is interesting in itself.

There is an immense amount of micromanagement in the game, especially when the fort becomes more populated, and that is sometimes great and sometimes a little tedious. Sometimes I would have four people in grave conditions idling about and one more available for work, but you can only queue two chores at a time and automode makes the survivors do dumb things like drink the last of the water tank when others are in more need, or eat from the spacious pantry instead of the maxed out freezer. Trauma right now is barely noticable even as you dig graves and bury your family members.

So all in all great game that holds a promise, I hope that similar to games like Prison Architect, The Long Dark and Rebuild 3 it would continue to grow and develop over time even after v1.0.

I would love it more if it had:
====================

1. More uses for attributes (INT, STR etc) indoors and outdoors and more rpg depth in the encounters, with more than one scene per encounter
2. Global control menu - I want to be able to tweak the automatic behavior of the fort globally - switch on / off the toilet when there's no water for instance, guide survivors to eat meat.
3. Moar Traits - I don't want to say steal a feature, but in the game Pixel Pirate some actions can be learned and trigger automatically as a charecter levels up. In Sheltered I'm thinking pooping automatically, learning to clean up after yourself, wanting to fix stuff when you're idle, healing survivors, reading books.
4. Characters interacting in game - If you've played This War of Mine, there's a lot of emphasis there about the tolls of hiding in. Contradictory traits leading to arguments and fights, cabin fever and trauma can play a part in the simulation and add a lot to the atmosphere and gameplay.
5. Cooperation - if we have sims mechanics, charecters should also be able to do things with and for each other:  cook for several people, high INT help traumatized or dress wounds, digging a new room together.
6. Names - more diverse name generator in the game, I had three Lindas at one point :)
7. A queue of three or five actions at a time, and survivors can wait for someone to finish using the toilet (maybe get some stress)

That's it. Nice to see Team17 again.

Not an inherently bad game truth be told, in fact I have high hopes for this game. Obviously to begin there were several bugs, and as time has gone on they have been shot down. But if you're in the market for a somewhat good survival game wherein you have to pay attention to a full family in a shelter, I would recommend this game. A tip a well though, as the tutorial requires work, the Home button makes characters automatically do what they need to; eat, sleep, drink, etc. And as of now, its a bit of a tedious venture to be honest. I'm hopeful though, that with time and effort the developers can produce more and more that you can do within the confines of what is left of the civilized world.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great little game, lots of fun.

The concept is simple enough, you manage a small family of four that managed to not only survive the apocalypse, but also happened across a small bomb shelter. You will need to manage your precious resources, expand your shelter, build what few comforts you can, explore your surroundings, trade, recruit, and kill to survive as long as possible.

Currently the game is still in Early Access but you will quickly see that the dev team is very involved and regularly adding in new updates. So if there is a mechanic you hate, or one you would like to see implemented its not too late to bring it up. Also having bought into many an Early Access title I too have been burned more than once by a dev team that got in over their heads or decided to cut and run. I don't get that impression from these guys, so if your hesitant about buying into a game that is still in Early Access out of fear of getting an unfinished game that will never get completed, don't worry about it with Sheltered. Its pretty clear that these folks have every intention of finishing what they have started.

Now yes there are a few bugs and minor issues. nothing that is game breaking that I've encountered so far. Just some things that won't close when you click on them so you have to hit esc. Things like that. And considering they just did an update this morning, I can see they are still adding in content and fixing bugs. And new content is always fun.

All in all yes I recommend this. Its fun, and addictive. The team appears to be very dedicated. There is a small learning curve and the tutorial needs some work. But after you play around with things for you first couple families, you'll have it down and will be expanding from a family into a post-apocalyptic, underground, community.

Too much micro managment. The inablity to set up routines of any kind for anyone. After a while it gets stupidly tiresome going though the day to day repairs, when I should just be able to have daily maintence" as a chore. But instead I have to navigate the nonexistant UI to acomplish anything.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The reliance on the RNG to be on your side is very high. Prepare to start over quite a few times through circumstances you can't avoid.

You need to be lucky enough to find the right material in the right amounts, while hoping that nothing bad happens to anyone.

Rain can be very unpredicatble. Some times you can wait days and only receive enough to fill 20 or 30 water even with an upgraded filter. This can leave you unable to leave your shelter to continue to collect other items leading to a spiral of defeat.

Sometimes you get random people that join you beyond your starting family of 4. These people will do absolutely nothing but consume resources for at least 20-30 minutes of real time. After an eternity of waiting on them to eat and drink their bloody fill, they'll finally go on expeditions. Once you run out of gas masks, and if they get radiation sickness, then you have 2 options. Use the pills or let them die. If you kick them out of the shelter before they die, they get angry and ruin your buildings.

You can get attacked by bandits and at the point of this writing, you cannot do anything except hide from them.

You can build Hiding Spots. It can be difficult to find enough hinges for every person you have.

All the items you need to be more efficient come at workbench level 3 and 4 and it can be quite tough to get to that point.

In this, you're relying on a lot of RNG, and not all that much strategy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a very good game in terms of addictiveness. However, there are still some changes that need to be made, as is expected. This game details your personal journey surviving a post-apocalyptic wasteland. I myself like to play this game often.
The changes I mentioned before and are being a constant hassle for many players:
Raiding. If a character has a courageous trait, they should be able to stand up and fight, instead of huddling in the corner. This I experienced, and one of my characters died, when 1 or 2 of my characters should have been able to fight.
Next, there is the matter of the mysterious hatch. The community would like a way to find this code, and possible somewhat easy, such as doing a favour for a random person.
Also, there is not enough diversity in the characters, pets and enemies.
There will be more problems popping up, but these need to be addressed first.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[Early Access Review]
Wow, even at EA, this game has me hooked!  I have created, lost and (sometimes) purposefully destroyed several families and innocent passer-bys in relentless pursuit of MORE STUFF!  No house, school or farm is safe from my raiding parties (sometimes a lone child...!).  The replayability is great and I love how the world is generated at every new game.  Some starts are failures from the get go and others have been remarkably lucky - it makes playing the game interesting and requires good strategies in being to cope with what you have.

The graphics are basic, but that is not what lured me in.  This is the kind of game that could eat away at your life, one hour at a time and you will happily let it.  The devs are responsive and eager for feedback from the community - the good reason to release an early access game :)

I really look forward to seeing how this game will evolve.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 15: I finally accepted a stranger into the shelter. He seemed fine at first, but he was freaking out way too much about some minor water issues. It got to a point where I sent him outside without a radiation suit to die, but then it rained so I let him come back, and he calmed down.

How many days can YOU last??

It's early access, so if you want a 'perfect' game, you should wait before you buy. Searching for all developer posts on the steam discussion forum helps to understand everything better. Documentation will be added and bugs will be solved with time. I'm having a lot of fun! The developers are quite active on the steam discussion forum, there's a 'report a problem' sub-forum for bugs. I'll be keeping a close eye on the steam update history page for the patch notes, it only gets better from here!!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This was one of the few games I was hyped for and let me say I wasn't disappointed like I am for most games. The pixel graphic would put some people off but I found them quite charming. There where a couple of things that bugged me that I don't remember, but I'm really enjoying caring for my low pixel count family and eating the dead.
Was a bit annoying to see it come out with EA, but I understand the need for them to do so. All in all, I'd give it a soft 8/10, mostly because I'm easily impressed. If you liked games like The Sims and/or This War of Mine, you might enjoy this game.
Also, lets you role play as yourself with a nuclear harem as to distract you from the crippling loneliness.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is like if Fallout and Sims had a 2D baby, its glorious.

As I write this the game is still an early access game with two updates already added to resolve some bugs and to balance the game a little better. The developers are very quick and efficient at getting back to you on any bug reports you make. So far I've seen fast fixes and lots of interraction with the community, definitely a positive sign of whats to come.

Of course right now there are some minor issues to be ironed out, but overall it's certainly playable. Any bugs experienced can be reported and members have found ways to fix" some of the bugs whilst ingame so you can still continue to play. I definitely believe it's worth the price of $16.99 as it stands. It's exciting to see updates to improve the game and anticipating new features.

It's very difficult to begin with and you're likely to have some failed run throughs. Just go with the flow and test things out
date: let yourself make mistakes and it'll help you improve your next game. Its very addictive to go through family after family mixing and matching traits and personalities
recommended: seeing what suits you best.\n\nEveryone has their own way of managing their shelter
hoursPlayed: some wipe out the innocent children while others protect them at all costs. Water and Food are important components and you need to be thoughtful of every action you do
voteText:
some can have terrible consequences. Its far too easy to become attached to one of the family members just to have them die. Dad Daderson will never be forgotten. He was a true hero who sacrificed himself to let the kids survive because I forgot to add fuel to the generator and radiation seeped in.

So far I've made it past Day 100 with all four family members and their cat intact and very much alive. They have even welcomed one stranger into their home. The household is still going stong and it will be heartbreaking when one of them finally does die. I've spent way too many hours playing this and many other games. Its a challenge for yourself to see how many days you can last. I've set the challenge to keep all my family members intact. I did plan to kill off the kids once but I couldn't face sending little Timmy out into the world without his gas mask.

10/10 would buy this game again."

Great game! Totally recommend it but i have some suggestions...


Ehh hello, Im a new member to this community and have played the game for a decent time now (played some hours). And now Im here to give my opinion and suggestions. First of all finding food is WAY too easy, I mean please by day 30 I had over 100 food lower the food-finding chances, please. Not being a cry-baby but please lower the chances. Second, raids tell me how many raids did any of you guys have? Well i got raided ONCE in 150 days. In my opinion the raid chances should be higher so the game is more challenging. Third, the maximum times you can expand your base is too little in my opinion one of these days you’ll need extra room for storage or gadgets you find while exploring the wasteland. Fourth, beginning “Small Pantries” and “Small Water Butt” uhh, please enable a deconstruct option for those. Fifth, backpacks/satchels when I send survivors out into the evil, wicked wasteland i keep running out of space i suggest adding a bigger backpack (like a tier 5 or something like that). Sixth, boring, boring, boring, waiting for your lame, old recycling plant *yes!*. The recycling plant takes way too long to process trash P.D add more trash finds.
