reviewText:
Sheltered is a lot of fun... for a while. I'll explain that later.

But first lets look at the game itself. You live in a shelter set in a post-apocalyptic area that is, of course, irradiated. You can get rad poisoning, food poisoning, basically any kind of poisoning. (including cookie poisoning... not really.) You explore (go on expeditions) this area and get supplies from the many question marks on your map. They can be houses and caves and such. But you can also meet others in the wastes, and depending on where you are they can be friendly or hostile. In these human encounters you can recruit, trade, bully (essentially fight), or flee. Trading is pretty-self explanatory, just click on the things you want, and then give them something that has the same amount of value points as the other item does. Bullying is basically just killing the person for what you want. Fleeing is also self-explanatory. Recruiting is pretty easy to do as often times the people you meet are desperate.

Now onto the mechanics.

Since it is a post-apocalyptic wasteland you need food and water. Water is obtained through rain and expeditions. Food is obtained through expeditions and traps that you can set outside. You will also need gasoline to fuel your shelter. Yes, you have lights and things. You can build more rooms in your shelter to expand room for more buildings. You build, build, build, build, build, build, until you can build no more. You can get quests from people and give them things.

But that's about it. Don't get me wrong, I love the game, but I didn't get that much playtime out of it. I am stuck at a point where I can do about anything because I have such a large water supply, and enough resources to get food from animals. Again, I do not think this game is bad, but I just don't know what else to do.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a very good game in terms of addictiveness. However, there are still some changes that need to be made, as is expected. This game details your personal journey surviving a post-apocalyptic wasteland. I myself like to play this game often.
The changes I mentioned before and are being a constant hassle for many players:
Raiding. If a character has a courageous trait, they should be able to stand up and fight, instead of huddling in the corner. This I experienced, and one of my characters died, when 1 or 2 of my characters should have been able to fight.
Next, there is the matter of the mysterious hatch. The community would like a way to find this code, and possible somewhat easy, such as doing a favour for a random person.
Also, there is not enough diversity in the characters, pets and enemies.
There will be more problems popping up, but these need to be addressed first.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI bought this game on early access some months ago when less of the glitches were resolved and honestly it was worth it even then. This game is very good at making you feel like you are trying to survive something. Finding the basic resources needed to prevent starvation is challenging. Food can be caught but the traps are consumable items. You have to scavenge the wastelands fairly often to survive properly.  You have to micromanage every need your characters have including stress reduction and trauma recovery.  And everything you use practically is falling apart with every use so you have to repair it.  It is suitably hard.  I found also that the glitches I experienced during play were resolved with updates in a timely manner.  Worth every cent even in the stage I bought it in.

reviewText:
I love this game. I've put over 100 hours into it since I got it on tuesday. As a big fan of This War of Mine, I was looking for something similar and yet different. I was not disappointed in the slightest, like the twisted love child of This War of Mine and Fallout, I enjoyed every step of the way.

I have seen several reviews citing a lack of autonomy with the automatic players, or that the radio goes off too many times. My response to them is to not use automatic, and if you cannot keep up with the radio (simply by presing R you lazy twits), then don't send out so many search parties at once. Automatic play is nearly pointless, but I never use it on games like this anyway. It can get to be a busy game as your shelter expands, but that's the whole point! Would you rather just sit there, occasionally glancing up to see if you're being attacked? How boring!

My only complaint is content! Not that the game lacks it, I just crave more! This game has some serious potential to be an amazing game! It already is to me, but give me one or two heavy expansions or some workshop content to expand on a base game that is already fantastic! I would like more variations in questing as well. Variations in creatures as well would be great, we see them discussing mutants and the like but all I've ever run into is bears, wolves, and people.

Also, why aren't you able to brew alcohol or grow marijuana? That would virtually cure your trauma right on the spot!

I discovered last night that once you complete a quest after the RV is fixed you can move on to a new area! Holy sheeiiittteee militia! Such an awesome game! Buy it!

reviewText:
Great game that got me hooked immediately and I recommend buying it now - v1.0 straight out of early access. I am very excited to see it develop over time (and hope it will).

The atmosphere and mechanics are great, permadeath deletes your save slot, the genre is a combination of the sims and cannibalism in 2d. You craft the familiar crop of gear, furniture and traps for your family's survival, alongside some cool machinery for your fort like a recycling plant and an indoor plant nursery. People offer to join your fort or attack you in the wilderness, and you can choose to confront or try to escape tough situations.

BONUS 1: the wood and pipe resources are also weapons
BONUS 2: family members drag bodies outside and bury them

The obvious things to expect in terms of improvements in the coming versions are probably the RPG and encounter depth, the combat system and maybe tweaks to control of the survivors' daily life. It seems like the gear is well balanced, except for the fuel system. There's too much fuel in the game, the generator uses very little, and the unit price is high. This tiny flaw along with the high price of records, bears and tools, makes the money aspect of trading less interesting. Instead, the availability of goods dictates the progress in certain stages, which is interesting in itself.

There is an immense amount of micromanagement in the game, especially when the fort becomes more populated, and that is sometimes great and sometimes a little tedious. Sometimes I would have four people in grave conditions idling about and one more available for work, but you can only queue two chores at a time and automode makes the survivors do dumb things like drink the last of the water tank when others are in more need, or eat from the spacious pantry instead of the maxed out freezer. Trauma right now is barely noticable even as you dig graves and bury your family members.

So all in all great game that holds a promise, I hope that similar to games like Prison Architect, The Long Dark and Rebuild 3 it would continue to grow and develop over time even after v1.0.

I would love it more if it had:
====================

1. More uses for attributes (INT, STR etc) indoors and outdoors and more rpg depth in the encounters, with more than one scene per encounter
2. Global control menu - I want to be able to tweak the automatic behavior of the fort globally - switch on / off the toilet when there's no water for instance, guide survivors to eat meat.
3. Moar Traits - I don't want to say steal a feature, but in the game Pixel Pirate some actions can be learned and trigger automatically as a charecter levels up. In Sheltered I'm thinking pooping automatically, learning to clean up after yourself, wanting to fix stuff when you're idle, healing survivors, reading books.
4. Characters interacting in game - If you've played This War of Mine, there's a lot of emphasis there about the tolls of hiding in. Contradictory traits leading to arguments and fights, cabin fever and trauma can play a part in the simulation and add a lot to the atmosphere and gameplay.
5. Cooperation - if we have sims mechanics, charecters should also be able to do things with and for each other:  cook for several people, high INT help traumatized or dress wounds, digging a new room together.
6. Names - more diverse name generator in the game, I had three Lindas at one point :)
7. A queue of three or five actions at a time, and survivors can wait for someone to finish using the toilet (maybe get some stress)

That's it. Nice to see Team17 again.

reviewText: When it comes to simulation games,  there are two kinds of player; macromanagers and micromanagers.  The former prefers to make generalized decisions and allow the specific details to be handled within the ai.   The latter prefers to manage every detail of the process,  and their gameplay is a collection of their smaller choices aggregated.  Macromanagers for instance leave free will on when playing THE SIMS whereas micromanagers turn it off or override it often.  SHELTERED is a game for the micromanagers.  I am not one of those.\n\nWhile the premise and depth is great and I can tell the execution here is good,  the biggest flaw I found was a lack of AI in the family members.  They won't do any task unless commanded.   Mom will happily stand outside dying of radiation poisoning while standing next to the damaged air filter with no hazmat suit on,  and will make no effort at all to put on said rad suit and fix the filter unless specifically commanded.  This is true of everyonr;  you must issue commands to get people to do anything,  and they won't grab a gas mask or rad suit unless you walk them through the steps of doing so each time they go outaide.   This sort of play got old with me quickly,  but a micromanager would likely love it.    6/10 but not for all gamers.

reviewText:
Some issues I have with the game have been fixed. Good on you devs.

=============================================================

Same as the other negative reviews. The game has potential. But it's filled with small, annoying and sometimes game ruining instances of developer oversight. Some examples.

Water being wasted on expeditions when they SUCCESFULLY END. Such as  the expidition getting good loot on its first location. So you recall. And lose 90% of the water.

Irreplacable pets. Really? There are no stray dogs/cats/wild horses left in the world?

Numerous others.

Too much micro managment. The inablity to set up routines of any kind for anyone. After a while it gets stupidly tiresome going though the day to day repairs, when I should just be able to have daily maintence" as a chore. But instead I have to navigate the nonexistant UI to acomplish anything.

My ♥♥♥♥ing battle hardened serial killers that I unleashed upon the surface and that have literally killed ♥♥♥♥ing hundreds COWER IN FEAR AS TWO PEOPLE IN ♥♥♥♥ING KHAKIS INVADED MY HOME AND KILLED THEM WITH PICKAXES.

I'm more impressed that this is even possible. Think about it for a moment.  How could ANYONE have thought this was a good
date:
immersive player experience. It actually baffles me. There's literally zero interaction between the amount of murder I inflict and my ability to defend my base. Or the dozens of guns I've horded.

This will stay negative until quality of life changes actually hit.

It's too bad
recommended: really. It had the makings of an excelent game."

reviewText:
There's a lot here and I've enjoyed it, but a warning: it's half-baked. So for now, I have to recommend against buying the game until it's had a bunch more work to make it complete. I'll be keeping an eye on the release updates to see when to come back to it.

In amongst the pretty solid (but a little grindy) shelter building gameplay, there's a bunch of UI annoyances and busy-work. The fun of exploring, of building up the base and keeping everyone alive is counterweighed by the tedium of constantly maintaining things, or finding things for the Sims" to do in the shelter. Otherwise they just stand around.

And there's some pretty rough UI issues too. The biggest one is that you can't move the info panels in the shelter view
date: which means you can't see your front door
recommended: and often the generator is obscured. The bottom of the screen is almost always empty - why aren't the info panels there?\n\nI've had many of my team fall dead some time after coming back from an expedition and I'm not entirely sure why! I think some of them might have been in a fight
hoursPlayed:
but then other times I check on people who've been in a fight (to bleeding) and when they get back they don't need any particular attention...

There's also some real oddities like not being able to move around (or destroy in the case of the first storage box) some of the early game objects. Can't move the cat's feed bowl... or the stuff near the door when you're making defences.

Then there's that weird "confirm" dialog "option" you always have to click on in encounters. It doesn't do anything
voteText: but you have to click on that word anyway."

reviewText: I like this game a lot. It's almost everything I'd like in an apocalypse sort of setting. If you liked Oregon Trail then you'll probably like this game. It has a very similar feel. I only have a few complaints in that I wish you could save families so when mine dies horribly I wouldn't have to meticulously recreate them every new save. reviewText: Extremely addicting and extremely good. Mechanics are fine, some of them you won't know until it's too late  like the fact that it's required to upgrade the air filter before recruiting a certain amount of people, which will suffocate everyone inside the shelter, kill some people and make others to raid and sabotage it, and that some recruits are psychopaths and will kill your family( there's no way to find it out before it's too late). Be warned. , it will make you spend several hours without feeling it and the OST gives a quite dark feeling .Combat is turn based and can be avoided most times\n\nTL;DR: Game is addicting, good/great OST, will make you quest your morals and make you think twice before taking decisions and trusting people.

reviewText:
Please note this is all in my opinion and probably isn't how you are supposed to play the game. Now, please enjoy
tl:dr at bottom

After 9 nonstop hours of playing this game and getting to day 300ish, I feel like I have pretty good grounds to review this game.

Well to start off you will constantly be learning on how to play the game, be that from the informative albeit small ten minute learning curve that you first get when you start up a game or when you first find out that this game suffers from an extreme repetition problem along with some serious RNG (random number generator). Don't get me wrong, this game is the ♥♥♥♥, but the majority if not all of your gameplay will be following a pattern not because it is the only thing you can do, but because its pretty much the most feasible way to play. For example, encounters;

When you explore the wasteland you will encounter people or animals that will cause your characters to react in a certain way which in turn levels them up a certain way. You can use upgrades like camo clothing to negate these encounters, but I have found no benefit in doing so. When you encounter said... encounters, you will pretty much do the following;

1. You meet a stranger in the wilderness. Before you say anything he offers to trade. He has only garbage, you reject, he gets offended and you part ways.
2. You meet a stranger who starts saying how futile life is and insults you. You will beat his stinky hobo ♥♥♥ into the ground, take his cement and batteries and move on.
3. You meet a stranger offering to join. Since this is the first stranger that offers to join, you accept him into your shelter only to find that he is garbage in everything but charisma and has the heavy eater perk.
4. You meet a stranger offering to join. Since this is not your first time a stranger has offered to join, you reject him on the spot and manage to save both you and your children's life from water contamination when you eventually kick him out for being worthless.
5. You meet a stranger and before she can say anything you kill him for his/her cement and batteries and move on.
6. You encounter a bear and ♥♥♥♥ing die on the first turn (unless you have doggo).

After you return home from your wasteland adventures, you will find your house in ruin. Your water and oxygen filters have broken, your toilet is broken and there is dog ♥♥♥♥ everywhere. After a brief cleaning and fixing period, you can set your supplies to good use. This is where that pattern problem comes in again. You will build as many new bunker segments as you can because you are essentially in a cubicle when you first start and have no room to put the bucket your wife and children have been ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in. Then you will focus purely on bags to allow you to bring more cement and batteries home for the cement and battery hoard. Then, you will repair your things again as the integrity system in this game is broken af. For the remainder of the time you will be getting your stats down so you can immediately go back into the burning wasteland of death to find more useless garbage you can't actually store at home but are just to lazy to not bring with you.

During this entire process you are going to have tens of thousands of people trying to dump their ♥♥♥♥ on you or live with you but you will have to turn down because of the ravenous appetite of your dog. The best ways to fight these guys off is to imagine they are all thieves and cannibals trying to get into your shelter and steal your cement and batteries and you won't feel as bad as you normally would when you send a person to death in the scorching desert.

You will repeat this process for almost ten hours until you start hearing this really upbeat music that sounds like it came out of the B list of Undertale. You will then find a person, 75 percent a woman, breaking down the door with a pickaxe. Since you spent all of your supplies on new bunker segments and not traps, you are going to do the next best logical thing. You put your kids in the basement and your adults up the top to fend off this one probably weak from starvation and dehydration woman. After you realize you can't fight back both of the parents will die like ♥♥♥♥♥es even though they have killed hundreds of people out in the wasteland with little trauma to boot. Some of your stuff will be taken, and you will continue along with the game. In most games losing two party members is essentially a death threat, but it just turns Sheltered into a really ♥♥♥♥ed up Home Alone movie. You will repeat the previous steps everyday and when you get the achievement for you 100 days alive you will start to wonder if you even needed parents in the first place.


tl:dr

So overall I had a lot of fun with this game and I really recommend it to anyone who likes games like This War of Mine because it looks like this game is just a pixelated heavily expanded upon version of it. The game was really hard until I found that if you click on the portraits you can automate the characters needs and that really takes away a lot of the frustration of micromanaging your people.

8/10 IGN Not Enough Water
